content.question: Fuselage contribution to directional stability is (I)_____ when its AC is (II)_____ of the CG?

options.C: (I) destabilising; (II) behind.

key_points: DIRECTIONAL STATIC STABILITY The primary source of directional instability is the aircraft fuselage
This is so because the subsonic aerodynamic centre (AC) of a typical fuselage usually lies ahead of the aircraft centre of gravity
Therefore, a positive sideslip angle will produce a negative yawing moment about the CG
learning.explanation: DIRECTIONAL STATIC STABILITY The primary source of directional instability is the aircraft fuselage. This is so because the subsonic aerodynamic centre (AC) of a typical fuselage usually lies ahead of the aircraft centre of gravity. Therefore, a positive sideslip angle will produce a negative yawing moment about the CG. Consequently, if CG moves aft, directional stability reduces. If this aerodynamic centre is ahead of aircraft centre of gravity, as is usually the case, the effect is destabilizing.

options.C: Line 4.

key_points: Static longitudinal stability depends upon the relationship of angle of attack and pitching moment (CM)
A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability
In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution
learning.explanation: Static longitudinal stability depends upon the relationship of angle of attack and pitching moment (CM). A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability. In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution. If the incidence of all surfaces remains fixed, the effect of CG position on static longitudinal stability is typified by the chart in figure 1: As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. The neutral point defines the most aft CG position without static instability. Positive static stability is indicated by the curve with negative slope. Moving the CG forward, will increase static longitudinal stability and this is represented by a (steeper) negative slope. Neutral static stability would be the result if the curve had zero slope. If neutral stability existed, the airplane could be disturbed to some higher or lower lift coefficient without change in pitching moment coefficient. An airplane which demonstrates a positive slope of the CM versus CL curve would be unstable.

In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution. As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. The neutral point may be imagined as the effective aerodynamic center of the entire airplane configuration, i.e. with the CG at the neutral point, all changes in net lift effectively occur at that point and no change in pitching moment results. The neutral point defines the most aft CG position without static instability. For an airplane to always have positive longitudinal static stability the CG must be ahead of the neutral point, so that the wing-pitching moment always exceeds the tail plane pitching moment. The further aft the neutral point is from the CG the greater is the static longitudinal stability.

content.question:
Complete the following statement:
Consider a wing with geometric positive dihedral in a sideslip. The dihedral (1) _____ contributes to static lateral stability, because the wing (2) _____ the wind is subject to an increase in angle of attack causing an increase in lift.

options.C: (1) positively; (2) into

key_points: DIHEDRAL If not corrected, an unstable aeroplane will side slip down when rolled to one side
This effect is not desirable, so how can we reduce it? By tilting the wingtips upwards, the aeroplane becomes naturally more stable in the lateral plane
This is called dihedral
learning.explanation: DIHEDRAL If not corrected, an unstable aeroplane will side slip down when rolled to one side. This effect is not desirable, so how can we reduce it? By tilting the wingtips upwards, the aeroplane becomes naturally more stable in the lateral plane. This is called dihedral. Lift acts perpendicular to the relative airflow. If the aeroplane rolls to the side when disturbed by a gust of wind, the lift vector leans to the side with the aeroplane. This creates a resultant sideways facing force that makes the aeroplane side slip in the same direction. As a result of this side slip, the aeroplane is subjected to a sideways component of the relative airflow. Due to dihedral, the lower wing (into the wind) meets the upcoming airflow at a greater angle of attack than the upper wing. Consequently, the lower wing produces more lift and helps the aeroplane roll back to its original position. This is how dihedral improves lateral stability.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Assuming no pilot input the motion of the aeroplane in the diagram shows:

options.C: static longitudinal instability.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

content.question: The contribution of wing sweep back to static directional stability is:

options.C: negative
options.D: positive or negative depending on sweepback angle

key_points: Sideslip develops whenever an aircraft rolls away from wings level
With a swept wing in a sideslip, the low wing will have an increase in CL, because the low wing effectively becomes a straight wing, while the high wing effectively becomes more swept
To add to that, the low wing increases in AR (Aspect Ratio), while the high wing decreases in AR
learning.explanation: Sideslip develops whenever an aircraft rolls away from wings level. With a swept wing in a sideslip, the low wing will have an increase in CL, because the low wing effectively becomes a straight wing, while the high wing effectively becomes more swept. To add to that, the low wing increases in AR (Aspect Ratio), while the high wing decreases in AR. Both of these will increase the lift on the low wing, and restore the aircraft to level flight, hence the high static lateral stability of swept wing aircraft. We also know that if you increase the lift, you increase the drag. So, it will have a slight tendency to yaw into the relative airflow (as there is more drag on the low wing), thereby contributing to static directional stability. This is a very small factor compared to the directional stability provided by the vertical fin but it does contribute to it. So it is positive.

content.question: Following a disturbance, an aeroplane oscillates about the lateral axis at constant amplitude. The aeroplane is:

options.C: statically unstable – dynamically stable.

key_points: Dynamic stability is said to be present if, after a disturbance upon the aircraft that disrupted its intended flight path, the aircraft damps these oscillations
Static stability is said to be present if the aircraft, after a disturbance upon the aircraft that disrupted its intended flight path, it counteracts this effect
For example, if a gust causes the airplane to have a nose up momentum, the airplane automatically reduces the angle of attack and goes nose down
learning.explanation: Dynamic stability is said to be present if, after a disturbance upon the aircraft that disrupted its intended flight path, the aircraft damps these oscillations. Static stability is said to be present if the aircraft, after a disturbance upon the aircraft that disrupted its intended flight path, it counteracts this effect. For example, if a gust causes the airplane to have a nose up momentum, the airplane automatically reduces the angle of attack and goes nose down. The aircraft oscillates around the lateral axis at a constant amplitude, meaning that it pitches up and down the same amount every time. The aircraft is statically stable, as the nose comes down after it has been up for a while. The aircraft is dynamically neutral, as it is not damping the oscillations, but not making them worse either.

The tail plane and elevators act as a horizontal stabilizer and the degree of positive longitudinal static stability that they provide is dependent on the size of the restoring moment they can attain; nevertheless, they make the largest contribution to the longitudinal static stability

The tail plane and elevators act as a horizontal stabilizer and the degree of positive longitudinal static stability that they provide is dependent on the size of the restoring moment they can attain; nevertheless, they make the largest contribution to the longitudinal static stability. The tail plane design and the length of the moment arm from the tail plane CP to the CG condition the magnitude of the restoring moment.

content.question: Flying an aircraft with a joystick, if a small displacement of the joystick results in a large change in pitch/bank angle, the aeroplane is decribed as being...

options.C: nose heavy.

key_points: An aircraft's stability affects many aspects of its flight characteristics
For an aircraft to be considered statically stable, it must initially begin to return to its original position/orientation after some sort of displacement
Think of placing a ball in a bowl, it will always begin to roll back to the bottom of the bowl, the equilibrium point
learning.explanation: An aircraft's stability affects many aspects of its flight characteristics. For an aircraft to be considered statically stable, it must initially begin to return to its original position/orientation after some sort of displacement. Think of placing a ball in a bowl, it will always begin to roll back to the bottom of the bowl, the equilibrium point. An aircraft can have stability in all three axes, pitch (longitudinal stability), yaw (directional stability) and roll (lateral stability). The opposite of stability is manoeuvrability, and if the aircraft is very stable, it is not very manoeuvrable, and vice-versa. The less stable (more manoeuvrable) we make an aircraft, the more easily it will change orientation. This is why aerobatic aircraft have very light controls, meaning that even small stick forces will cause a large aircraft movement, whereas stable aircraft, such as transport jets, are very stable, and will require much larger stick movements, and more stick force, to provide the same amount of aircraft movement. This is called stick force stability, which is a measure of how much input force is required to cause a 1G change. This question is asking about stick displacement, but it is largely the same thing. It is the reason that you would not want to cruise a highly aerobatic aircraft for long distances, as the fineness of control is difficult to achieve when the controls are so light and tiny movements cause huge changes. To answer the question, if small movements of the stick create large pitch/roll changes, the aircraft must be highly manoeuvrable. Interestingly, modern fighter aircraft, such as the Eurofighter Typhoon, are designed to be statically unstable for highest manoeuvrability, and have very responsive fly-by-wire controls making sure that the aircraft does not become unstable during flight. Excellent for air-to-air combat, terrible if they lose their FBW system.

content.question: Consider a swept back wing, with a sideslip to the right. The right wing experiences (I)_____ sweep, (II)_____ lift, and that provides (III)_____ lateral stability.

options.C: (I) more; (II) more; (III) positive.

key_points: Sideslip to the right means that the aircraft is pointing forwards but going rightwards, therefore the airflow is coming from the right hand side
Another way to think of this is that on approach, the runway will be out of the right hand side window, even if there is no crosswind
Wing sweep will help increase lateral stability
learning.explanation: Sideslip to the right means that the aircraft is pointing forwards but going rightwards, therefore the airflow is coming from the right hand side. Another way to think of this is that on approach, the runway will be out of the right hand side window, even if there is no crosswind. Wing sweep will help increase lateral stability. When a swept-wing airplane is sideslipping, the wing toward the sideslip will experience a higher velocity normal to the wing's leading edge than the wing away from the sideslip. More lift is generated on the wing toward the sideslip and a roll moment arises that tends to diminish the bank angle or sideslip and return the airplane to equilibrium. In this case, the airflow over the right wing becomes straighter (less swept). Straighter wings are effectively longer, so produce more lift, resulting in a larger rolling moment to the left returning the aircraft to a non-sideslipped condition. This is an example of positive lateral stability.

content.question: During a short period oscillation, the altitude:

options.A: varies significantly, as it does during a phugoid.
options.B: varies significantly, whereas during a phugoid it remains approximately constant.
options.C: remains approximately constant, whereas during a phugoid it varies significantly.
options.D: remains approximately constant, as it does during a phugoid.

key_points: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor
When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state
The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is normally heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

content.question: A forward CG shift:

options.A: has no influence on longitudinal manoeuvrability.
options.C: increases longitudinal manoeuvrability.

key_points: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP)
This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating
As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose.

key_points: Static directional stability is defined as the initial tendency of an aircraft to return to, or depart from, its equilibrium angle of sideslip (normally zero) when disturbed
When an aircraft is placed in a sideslip, aerodynamic forces develop which create moments about all three axes
The moments created about the normal-axis tend to turn the nose of the aircraft into or away from the relative wind
learning.explanation: Static directional stability is defined as the initial tendency of an aircraft to return to, or depart from, its equilibrium angle of sideslip (normally zero) when disturbed. When an aircraft is placed in a sideslip, aerodynamic forces develop which create moments about all three axes. The moments created about the normal-axis tend to turn the nose of the aircraft into or away from the relative wind. The aircraft has positive directional stability if the moments created by a sideslip angle tend to align the nose of the aircraft with the relative wind. If directional stability is excessive, high turn rate is provided by the moment. This can result in excessive back and forth (left – right) turning if the wind is coming from alternating left – right side. Thus, it will be difficult to control the aircraft in case of sideslip. The sideslip angle relates the displacement of the aeroplane centre line from the relative airflow

key_points: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability
In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution
As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable
learning.explanation: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability. In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution. As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. For an airplane to always have positive longitudinal static stability the CG must be ahead of the neutral point, so that the wing-pitching moment always exceeds the tail plane pitching moment. The further aft the neutral point is from the CG the greater is the static longitudinal stability.

learning.explanation: DUTCH ROLL Basically speaking, Dutch roll is a series of out-of-phase turns, when the aircraft rolls in one direction and yaws in the other. When the yaw is introduced, the strong “dihedral effect” will roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This occurs when a strong lateral stability is coupled with weak directional stability. With increasing altitude (decreasing density) or increasing Mach number, the possibility of a Dutch roll increases.

Learning Objective 081.04.04.05.01: Describe how the following aeroplane components contribute to static directional stability: wing; fin; dorsal fin; ventral fin; angle of sweep of the wing; angle of sweep of the fin; fuselage at high alpha; strakes. The vertical stabiliser (tail fin) of an aircraft is the main contributor to static directional stability (stability in yaw), as any sideslip angle will create a lift on the fin by introducing an angle of attack to its symmetrical aerofoil, which then will create a force on the aircraft to point into the relative airflow. From here on out, we are using the words, "positive effect" (on stability) to mean that it makes the aircraft more stable. The larger we make the tail fin, the larger the positive effect (on stability). Also, the further back we make the tail fin from the centre of gravity, the larger the moment arm of the force, so the larger the positive effect. For this question, we must remember that the fin is just a wing, but when we fly coordinated (no sideslip), it is a symmetrical aerofoil, so creating no lift in either direction. Introducing a sideslip (an angle of attack - AoA) causes a lift force to be made. The greater this force, the greater the "positive effect" on stability, which pushes the tail around so the nose points towards the relative airflow. Sweepback of a wing does a few things, it increases the MCRIT of the aerofoil by making it "effectively thinner", which is very useful for high speed flight. It also changes the low speed flying characteristics a lot, decreasing the coefficient of lift for each angle of attack, but increasing the critical (stalling) angle of attack (but with a lower maximum lift output). This last bit is particularly useful for aircraft. Swept back tail fins will remain useful at higher angles of sideslip before stalling, in comparison to straight fins. Increased sweepback of the tail fin usually has a negative effect on directional stability (stability in yaw). At low/medium sideslip angles, the reduced lift coefficient for each angle of attack produces less of a restoring force (the lower gradient on the graph above). It is important to note that at higher angles of attack, within a certain range, a straight fin will have stalled (so provides almost no stability) and the swept fin would not yet have stalled due to its higher stalling AoA, and in that case, the swept fin provides far more stabilising effect than a straight fin, but only within a certain range of large sideslip angles.

key_points: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP)
This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating
As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. If an aircraft is very stable (forward CG), the elevator will have to produce a bigger moment to move the pitch and thus requires a larger deflection, as the forces on the tailplane often are deflected downwards.

content.question: The maximum aft position of the centre of gravity is, amongst others, limited by the:

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”
The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves aft, the stick force gradient decreases with decreasing maneuvering stability and the lower limit of stick force gradient may be reached. The aft limit, which for safety reasons on a transport airplane is always forward of the neutral point, is confined by insufficient stick-force stability and/or excessive in-flight maneuverability. The minimum stick force per ‘g’ for the maximum permitted load factor, which is 2.5 for large transport airplanes, determines the aft limit of the CG envelope. A CG position aft of this point would produce an unacceptably low value of maneuver stability and would make the airplane difficult to fly. For transport airplanes the aft limit is normally located at approximately 30% of the MAC.

options.D: Ventral fins have no impact on the aircraft's longitudinal stability.

key_points: The aircraft fin is a very powerful stabilising element of an aircraft, and contributes to positive stability both directionally (stability in yaw), and laterally (stability in roll)
Some aircraft have more complex aerodynamical needs though, leading to the use of dorsal and/or ventral fins as well as the main tail fin

Dorsal fins are effectively just an extension to the main fin, extending forwards to provide some benefits such as the blending with the fuselage, reducing drag, providing better stability at high sideslip angles, etc
learning.explanation: The aircraft fin is a very powerful stabilising element of an aircraft, and contributes to positive stability both directionally (stability in yaw), and laterally (stability in roll). Some aircraft have more complex aerodynamical needs though, leading to the use of dorsal and/or ventral fins as well as the main tail fin. Dorsal fins are effectively just an extension to the main fin, extending forwards to provide some benefits such as the blending with the fuselage, reducing drag, providing better stability at high sideslip angles, etc. They therefore have a positive effect on directional and lateral stability. Ventral fins (sometimes called strakes), however, are placed under the fuselage, and provide a further increase in directional stability (yaw), but have the opposite effect to the main and dorsal fins when it comes to lateral stability, they are de-stabilising. Ventral fins are very useful for improving the stall/spin characteristcs of aircraft where the fuselage and wings may render the main fin less effective at high angles of attack (similar to a deep stall, but for stability). Their main limitation is ground clearance. None of these items have any effect on longitudinal stability, which is stability in pitch, as a pitch change will not cause any angle of attack change to these components. Some ventral fins/strakes are actually angled outwards, so they are not perfectly vertical. Now this would give very slightly increased longitudinal stability due to their location at the rear of the aircraft, however, the majority of ventral fins (as is the primary intention of them) have no effect on longitudinal stability.

content.question:
A large jet aircraft is designed to be operated with a positive longitudinal stability and is equipped with a Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system. Prior to each flight, the pilots input the aircraft mass and CG location into the Flight Management System (FMS). The aircraft's FMS then informs the FBW system of this data, allowing for the correct control forces and limitations to be used, giving flight envelope protection and ensuring stability is maintained.
Consider what will happen to the aircraft's high altitude handling characteristics if the pilot inputs the INCORRECT CG position into the FMS, located forward of the actual CG position. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Due to the design criteria applied, the longitudinal stability of the aircraft is always ensured, irrespective of the location of the CG.
options.B: The actual longitudinal stability is lower than calculated by the FBW system, and the system may allow for control surface deflections that result in instability.
options.C: The aircraft consumes more fuel than expected during the cruise phase of the flight, as the FBW system deflects the horizontal stabiliser more to counteract the error of the pilot.
options.D: The pitch rates commanded by the FBW system are lower at higher altitudes compared to the pitch rates required to ensure that the longitudinal stability remains positive.

key_points: An aircraft's stability, and in particular its longitudinal stability (stability in pitch) is massively dependent on the location of the aircraft's Centre of Gravity (CG)
As long as the CG is in front of the "neutral point", the aircraft will be longitudinally stable
The "neutral point" is a sort of average Centre of Pressure (CP) for the whole aircraft, and it goes towards where there are more aerodynamic surfaces
learning.explanation: An aircraft's stability, and in particular its longitudinal stability (stability in pitch) is massively dependent on the location of the aircraft's Centre of Gravity (CG). As long as the CG is in front of the "neutral point", the aircraft will be longitudinally stable. The "neutral point" is a sort of average Centre of Pressure (CP) for the whole aircraft, and it goes towards where there are more aerodynamic surfaces. Think of a throwing dart, the front had a weight and the back has a set of fins, therefore a very far forward CG and a far back "neutral point". This is a very stable system. A far forward CG therefore is a more stable condition. This also means a less manoeuvrable condition. Less manoeuvrability means that the pilot will have to push and pull harder on the controls to achieve the same result, as the control surfaces need to move further to achieve the same angular change. The controls feel "heavier" with a further forward CG, but the aircraft is more stable. This can be counteracted by the Fly-By-Wire system, which uses the knowledge of the aircraft's weight and CG position to estimate the required control surface deflection, and make the controls feel the same as for any other CG position, so the pilot has the same control of the aircraft, no matter the weight or CG position. If the CG is further forwards, the FBW system will amplify the pilot's inputs more than normal in the pitch axis, to make the aircraft control as it would do "normally". This means that, in this scenario, the pilot has entered an artificially far forward CG, so the FBW system will amplify the pilot's actions in pitch, but without any need to do so, as the CG is not actually that far forward. This could lead to overcontrolling of the aircraft by the fly-by-wire system, as the aircraft is not as stable as the FMS/FBW believes. The overcontrolling could potentially reduce the stability of the aircraft, or even cause instability. As this question is easy to misread or misunderstand, we will quickly go through each option: "Due to the design criteria applied, the longitudinal stability of the aircraft is always ensured, irrespective of the location of the CG." Whilst this looks plausible, the longitudinal stability is not ensured (and will be reduced or removed) when the CG goes out of the aft limit. "The actual longitudinal stability is lower than calculated by the FBW system, and the system may allow for control surface deflections that result in instability." As mentioned above, this is correct, due to the incorrectly entered CG position, which may allow the FBW to overcontrol the aircraft. The aircraft is less stable than the FBW system believes. "The aircraft consumes more fuel than expected during the cruise phase of the flight, as the FBW system deflects the horizontal stabiliser more to counteract the error of the pilot." The aircraft will actually consume less fuel than expected, but because the aircraft expects a forward CG in the cruise, which causes the tailplane to produce more downforce, and requires more lift from the wing, causing higher drag. However, the aircraft actually has a further aft CG, so will burn less fuel than expected. This is also not connected to the FBW system creating larger deflections, that is an effect which would occur in this case, but has negligible effect on fuel consumption. "The pitch rates commanded by the FBW system are lower at higher altitudes compared to the pitch rates required to ensure that the longitudinal stability remains positive." This has nothing to do with the scenario mentioned in the question (incorrectly inputted CG location).

content.question: An aircraft is trimmed so that after a disturbance in pitch, it starts an oscillatory motion that does not decrease over time. In this case, the aircraft has (1)_____ dynamic stability and (2)_____ static stability.

options.C: (1) neutral; (2) neutral

key_points: While static stability is concerned with the initial tendency of an aircraft to return to equilibrium, dynamic stability is defined by the resulting motion with time
If an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium, the time history of the resulting motion indicates its dynamic stability
Aircraft with neutral dynamic stability have oscillations that never dampen out
learning.explanation: While static stability is concerned with the initial tendency of an aircraft to return to equilibrium, dynamic stability is defined by the resulting motion with time. If an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium, the time history of the resulting motion indicates its dynamic stability. Aircraft with neutral dynamic stability have oscillations that never dampen out. If a trimmed and neutrally dynamic stable aircraft is pitched up, it pitches nose low, then nose high again, and this oscillation continues, in theory, forever.

content.question: A manufacturer shortens the fuselage of a 9 seat plane to a 6 seat plane. They make the vertical fin and horizontal stabiliser bigger. How is directional stability influenced?

options.A: There is no impact on stability.
options.B: Negative, since the bigger stabiliser produces more drag.
options.C: Positive, since the higher vertical fin.
options.D: The rudder effectiveness is highly reduced.

key_points: When a manufacturer shortens the fuselage of an aircraft from 9 seats to 6 seats, the aircraft's overall dimensions and weight change
In this case, the manufacturer has increased the size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer to account for the reduced fuselage length
The larger vertical fin provides greater surface area for controlling yaw, while the larger horizontal stabilizer increases pitch stability
learning.explanation: When a manufacturer shortens the fuselage of an aircraft from 9 seats to 6 seats, the aircraft's overall dimensions and weight change. In this case, the manufacturer has increased the size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer to account for the reduced fuselage length. The larger vertical fin provides greater surface area for controlling yaw, while the larger horizontal stabilizer increases pitch stability. The larger vertical fin increases the surface area available to resist the yawing moment caused by asymmetrical thrust, crosswinds, or other factors that could cause the aircraft to turn left or right. This results in improved directional stability of the aircraft, which means that it is less likely to deviate from its intended course. Therefore, option "Positive, since the higher vertical fin." is the correct answer. The increased size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer should not reduce the effectiveness of the rudder, as the rudder is the primary control surface for yaw control. In fact, the larger surface area of the vertical fin may even enhance the rudder's effectiveness, as it provides more area for the rudder to deflect and generate a yawing moment.

content.question: An aircraft has been placed in a spiral dive. The pilot has then let go of all the controls to see how the aircraft will naturally react. Its speed, rate of turn and rate of descent all begin decreasing. What type of spiral dive mode does the aircraft possess?

options.C: Unstable.

key_points: The feedback for this question was weak and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q814718 - originally seen in Austro Control), so any feedback you have about either of these questions from the real exam would be very useful to make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much
This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is almost trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing
The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability
learning.explanation: The feedback for this question was weak and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q814718 - originally seen in Austro Control), so any feedback you have about either of these questions from the real exam would be very useful to make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much. This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is almost trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing. The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability. Imagine an aircraft is disturbed to roll slightly right, and therefore takes up a slight right sideslip. The large fin yaws into the turn before the aircraft can roll out of it, and this yaw causes a further bank, which again causes more yaw before the aircraft can roll out of it. During this process, the nose keeps dropping to increase airspeed to maintain lift in the turn without any increase in angle of attack. In IMC without good use of instruments, this feels like straight and level flight until the G forces start to increase noticeably, at which point the pilot would finally notice that something was wrong, as they are in a high speed spiral dive. But now back to the theory. Many aircraft have a slight spiral instability, which, even though the aircraft might be statically stable in all axes, means that a small departure from straight and level will gradually become a spiral dive if no pilot inputs are made. As this is a gradual process, it is acceptable up to a certain rate of instability as the pilot can easily override it. Being stable in the spiral mode means that the aircraft naturally tends to reduce any spiral dives to zero. If an aircraft is stable in the spiral mode, then it is likely to have a strong tendency for dutch roll. For this question, then, if the aircraft's rate of turn, rate of descent and speed are all decreasing, then it is naturally rolling out of the turn, and is therefore stable in the spiral (dive) mode.

content.question: Why is it bad to have too much lateral stability?

options.C: More prone to Spiral dive

key_points: With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind
The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations
This is called Dutch roll
learning.explanation: With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the possibility of Dutch roll. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability.

key_points: DUTCH ROLL
This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip
Because of these characteristics of the Dutch roll oscillation, lateral dynamic stability has always been more of a problem than longitudinal dynamic stability
learning.explanation: DUTCH ROLL. This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip. Because of these characteristics of the Dutch roll oscillation, lateral dynamic stability has always been more of a problem than longitudinal dynamic stability. With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. With increasing altitude (decreasing density) or increasing Mach number, the possibility of a Dutch roll increases. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the likelihood of a Dutch roll.

learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. The point where the aircraft does not have any positive or negative static longitudinal stability, and therefore is static longitudinally neutral, is called the neutral point. Placing the CG aft of this point makes the aircraft unstable, placing the CG forward of this point makes the aircraft stable.

learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is usually heavily damped. key_points: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane
Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left

learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. The airplane design features that increase the lateral static stability are: dihedral. sweepback. high-wing mounting. increased effective dihedral. large, high vertical fin. low CG. The airplane design features that decrease the lateral static stability are: anhedral. forward-swept wings. ventral fin. low-wing mounting. extending inboard flaps.

The change in lift (side force) on the fin creates a yawing moment about the centre of gravity which tends to yaw the aeroplane into the relative airflow
learning.explanation: The fin (vertical stabilizer) is the major source of directional stability for the aeroplane. In a sideslip the fin experiences a change in angle of attack. The change in lift (side force) on the fin creates a yawing moment about the centre of gravity which tends to yaw the aeroplane into the relative airflow. The magnitude of the fin contribution to static directional stability depends on both the change in fin lift and the fin moment arm. The lift curve slope of the fin determines how sensitive the surface is to change in angle of attack. While it is desirable to have a high lift curve slope for the fin, a high aspect ratio surface is not necessarily practical or desirable due to: - Bending - Lower stalling angle - Hangar roof clearance The stall angle of the surface must be large enough to prevent stall and subsequent loss of effectiveness at expected sideslip angles. Sweepback or low aspect ratio increases the stalling angle of attack of the fin and reduces the lift curve slope, therefore reducing static directional stability.

As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. The neutral point may be imagined as the effective aerodynamic center of the entire airplane configuration, i.e. with the CG at the neutral point, all changes in net lift effectively occur at that point and no change in pitching moment results. The neutral point defines the most aft CG position without static instability. As seen in figure 1, neutral static stability would be the result if the curve had zero slope. For an airplane to always have positive longitudinal static stability the CG must be ahead of the neutral point, so that the wing-pitching moment always exceeds the tail plane pitching moment. The further aft the neutral point is from the CG the greater is the static longitudinal stability.

The position of the CG directly affects the magnitude of the longitudinal static stability, the tailplane downforce and the stalling speed because its position determines the length of the arm of any restoring moment. MANOEUVRING STABILITY The most direct appreciation of the manoeuvring stability of an aeroplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. key_points: The rotation of an aircraft about its normal, or vertical, axis is a yaw

If this movement is the result of an undesirable disturbance, then the ability of the airplane to return to its original heading without the assistance of any control-surface movement is a measure of its directional static stability
It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow
learning.explanation: The rotation of an aircraft about its normal, or vertical, axis is a yaw. If this movement is the result of an undesirable disturbance, then the ability of the airplane to return to its original heading without the assistance of any control-surface movement is a measure of its directional static stability. It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow. An airplane has directional static stability if, when in a sideslip with the airflow coming from the right initially the nose tends to yaw right. The drag of a swept wing is less than that of an unswept wing. The advantage of this type of wing at high speeds is gained at the expense of its poor performance at low speed. The drag experienced with a swept wing is the component of the relative airflow at 90◦ to the line joining the aerodynamic center of the wing, which if the wing has parallel leading and trailing edges will be the normal to the leading edge of the wing. In figure 1 the normal component of the relative airflow is greater on the port wing than the normal component on the starboard wing. The drag on the leading wing, the port wing, in figure 1 is of greater magnitude than that of the trailing starboard wing because of its decreased effective sweep angle. It is therefore a stabilizing influence. Positive sweepback has a stabilizing effect on directional stability because the CP is further aft, and the stalling angle is increased. The significance and magnitude of this effect on directional static stability is directly proportional to the angle of sweepback.

key_points: An airplane may display spiral instability in case it has strong directional stability relative to its lateral stability
It looks similar to a spin, however, the wings are not stalled here
When a wind gust makes an airplane with spiral instability to side-slip, powerful directional stability tends to yaw the airplane back into alignment with the relative wind
learning.explanation: An airplane may display spiral instability in case it has strong directional stability relative to its lateral stability. It looks similar to a spin, however, the wings are not stalled here. When a wind gust makes an airplane with spiral instability to side-slip, powerful directional stability tends to yaw the airplane back into alignment with the relative wind. In this case the outside wing will generate more lift as it travels faster. This tends to roll the airplane in the direction of the yaw. The rolling force overcomes the weak dihedral effect, allowing further roll. As the vertical component of lift decreases, the relative wind has an upward component with the airplane swinging in alignment with the air stream, the nose begins to drop. This results in a gradually increasing spiral dive. Note: Dutch Roll = may occur when static lateral stability is too high compared to the static directional stability.

key_points: SPIRAL INSTABILITY Spiral instability occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is strong and the lateral stability is weak
When a wing drops, due to a disturbance, the tendency of the aeroplane to correct this departure from the balanced condition in level flight is dependent on the lateral stability of the aeroplane
Additionally, when a wing drops, it causes other secondary motions to be initiated
learning.explanation: SPIRAL INSTABILITY Spiral instability occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is strong and the lateral stability is weak. When a wing drops, due to a disturbance, the tendency of the aeroplane to correct this departure from the balanced condition in level flight is dependent on the lateral stability of the aeroplane. Additionally, when a wing drops, it causes other secondary motions to be initiated. The fin and rudder tend to yaw the aeroplane into the airflow in the direction of the dropped wing. Because of the yaw, the higher wing on the outside of the turn is travelling faster than the lower wing and develops a greater amount of lift. This generates a rolling moment in the opposite direction to the correcting moment of the dihedral and if the rolling moment is greater it will tend to increase the angle of bank. If the rolling moment is of sufficient magnitude to overcome the correcting force, produced by the dihedral and the damping yaw effect, the bank angle will increase and the aeroplane will enter a steadily steepening spiral dive. This is spiral instability that can be described as a combined lateral and directional aperiodic motion.

learning.explanation: To overcome the instability in the fuselage it is possible to incorporate into the overall design dorsal or ventral fins. A dorsal fin is a small aero foil, of very low aspect ratio, mounted on top of the fuselage near the rear. A ventral fin is mounted below. If the aircraft is yawed to the right, the dorsal and ventral fins will create a side force to the right. The line of action of this force is well aft of the aircraft CG, giving a yawing moment to the left (a stabilizing effect). However, at small angles of yaw they are ineffective. Dorsal and ventral fins become more effective at relatively high sideslip angles. Due to their low aspect ratio, they do not tend to stall at any sideslip angle which an aircraft is likely to experience in service. While dorsal and ventral fins contribute positively to directional static stability, a dorsal fin contributes positively to lateral static stability, while a ventral fin is destabilizing in this mode and has no effect on longitudinal stability. It creates lift below CG in the direction of the roll.

learning.explanation: An airplane may display spiral instability in case it has strong directional stability relative to its lateral stability. It looks similar to a spin, however, the wings are not stalled here. When a wind gust makes an airplane with spiral instability to side-slip, powerful directional stability tends to yaw the airplane back into alignment with the relative wind. In this case the outside wing will generate more lift as it travels faster. This tends to roll the airplane in the direction of the yaw. The rolling force overcomes the weak dihedral effect, allowing further roll. As the vertical component of lift decreases, the relative wind has an upward component with the airplane swinging in alignment with the air stream, the nose begins to drop. This results in a gradually increasing spiral dive.

When the CG position of the aeroplane is fixed, each elevator position corresponds to a particular trim lift coefficient. As the CG is moved aft, the slope of this line decreases, and the decrease in stability is evident by a given control displacement causing a greater change in trim lift coefficient. key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

content.question: CS-23 and CS-25 require that an aeroplane must be statically stable and specify the acceptable range of stability and manoeuvrability. An aircraft's stability is affected by the CG location and the gross weight of the aircraft, amongst other factors. For a given aeroplane, the manoeuvrability...

options.A: cannot be affected by the pilot or operator as it is determined by the aircraft design.
options.B: is determined by the size of the control surfaces only, not the CG position or the weight.
options.C: is significantly higher when the centre of gravity is at the forward limit, and/or when the aeroplane is heavy.
options.D: tends to be reduced when the aeroplane is heavy or has a forward centre of gravity location.

key_points: This question is unnecessarily long and wordy, but does give some hints which help to remove incorrect options quickly
Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed
In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state
learning.explanation: This question is unnecessarily long and wordy, but does give some hints which help to remove incorrect options quickly. Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed. In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state. An aircraft's type of static stability is defined by its initial reaction after some external force is removed. We use the term "static" because we're only concerned with the initial tendency to return to equilibrium, without considering subsequent motion. Manoeuvrability, on the other hand, is the aircraft's ability to change its position or attitude in response to pilot inputs, allowing it to perform various manoeuvres. Stability and manoeuvrability are effectively opposite, and the greater an aircraft's stability, the lower the manoeuvrability, and vice-versa. An aircraft with a further forward CG has greater stability (but lower manoeuvrability) and aircraft with aft CG locations have lower stability, but higher manoeuvrability. Higher weight also tends to reduce manoeuvrability, but this rule isn't always as simple as the CG locations. The question tells us that stability is affected by the CG location and the gross weight of the aircraft, and, knowing that manoeuvrability and stability are closely (and inversely) linked, that hints to us that those factors also affect the manoeuvrability, which they do. That removes the following options: "cannot be affected by the pilot or operator as it is determined by the aircraft design.", as the CG location and weight can be affected by the operator/pilot, so therefore, the manoeuvrability can be too; and "is determined by the size of the control surfaces only, not the CG position or the weight.", as the manoeuvrability is changed by the CG location and weight. The other options can be chosen between based on the CG location and weight, and the effects of those mentioned above.

learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is normally heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

learning.explanation: An aircraft is said to be trimmed (in trim) if all moments in pitch, roll, and yaw are equal to zero. The term controllability refers to the ability of the aircraft to respond to control surface displacement and achieve the desired condition of flight. Adequate controllability must be available to perform take-off and landing and accomplish the various maneuvers in flight. A contradiction exists between stability and controllability. A high degree of stability gives reduced controllability. The relationship between static stability and controllability is demonstrated by figure 1 and 2. The effect of increased static stability (forward CG movement) on controllability is illustrated by the ball in a steeper trough (figure 2). A greater force is required to “control” the ball to the same position of displacement when the static stability is increased. In this manner, a large degree of static stability tends to make the aircraft less controllable. It is necessary to achieve the proper proportion between static stability and controllability during the design of an aircraft because too much static stability (forward CG position) reduces controllability. The forward CG limit is set to ensure minimum controllability.

key_points: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane
Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left
Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip
learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. The airplane design features that increase the lateral static stability are: dihedral. sweepback. high-wing mounting. increased effective dihedral. large, high vertical fin. low CG. The airplane design features that decrease the lateral static stability are: anhedral. forward-swept wings. ventral fin. low-wing mounting. extending inboard flaps.

content.question: When an aircraft enters a spiral dive with the CG at the AFT limit, when the spiral dive is fully developed, which of the following pitch attitudes is most likely?

options.C: Nose Level

key_points: Note: This is a completely different scenario to the similar questions that exist about spins
A spiral dive occurs when an aircraft is very directionally stable (stable in yaw) and not very laterally stable (stable in roll)

When a significant sideslip is induced, a stable aircraft will want to yaw very towards the oncoming airflow direction, and in a balanced aircraft, would also roll away from the oncoming airflow direction
learning.explanation: Note: This is a completely different scenario to the similar questions that exist about spins. A spiral dive occurs when an aircraft is very directionally stable (stable in yaw) and not very laterally stable (stable in roll). When a significant sideslip is induced, a stable aircraft will want to yaw very towards the oncoming airflow direction, and in a balanced aircraft, would also roll away from the oncoming airflow direction. However, the aircraft's roll would not be as strong in this scenario, and the strong yawing effect may even overpower it, which would cause the aircraft to yaw and roll towards the oncoming airflow. This intense yawing effect basically overpowers the other aspects of stability and makes the aircraft bank in the same direction, which forms a spiral dive. Spiral dives can make the aircraft speed up very quickly and can cause overspeed or overstress if not dealt with quickly, as they get worse with time. Spiral dives are referred to as "aperiodic" motion as they do not go back and forth (like dutch roll), they only happen once, getting further from equilibrium. The key part of this question is that spiral dives are always pointing downwards, as they are a dive. If the nose was upwards, they would be a stall/spin. Note that you can easily create an accelerated stall leading to a spin from a spiral dive, if handled incorrectly.

The aircraft may need to be trimmed in pitch as a result of: - changes of speed. - changes of power. - varying CG positions. - changes of configuration. A Trimmable Horizontal Stabiliser (THS) enables a larger CG and speed range than a conventional tailplane with stabiliser, elevator and trim tab, because the whole stabiliser may be moved for trimming the aeroplane, instead of a relatively “small” elevator and trim tab only (a larger surface is much more effective). key_points: The chord line that passes through the geometric centre of the plan area of an aerofoil is the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) and for any planform is equal to the chord of a rectangular wing having the same wing span and the same pitching moment and lift

Tail strike – the rotation is started before it is possible to lift-off, consequently angle of attack might be increased up to tail strike
learning.explanation: The chord line that passes through the geometric centre of the plan area of an aerofoil is the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) and for any planform is equal to the chord of a rectangular wing having the same wing span and the same pitching moment and lift. The MAC is often used to reference the location of the centre of gravity. Tail strike – the rotation is started before it is possible to lift-off, consequently angle of attack might be increased up to tail strike. In this case, a 12% CG position will tend to hold the nose down (nose-heavy). To counter this, the pilots need to set a nose up trim in order to create a nose-up pitching moment at rotation. The actual CG position is however more aft which will naturally help lifting the aircraft nose. This natural tendency, combined with a nose-up trim, will result in a tendency of the nose lifting of earlier than intended and faster, increasing the risk of a tail strike.

When you roll your aircraft to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn. For example, as you roll to the right, your aircraft may initially yaw to the left. When you roll your aircraft to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down. The aileron in the upward position (the right aileron in this example) creates less lift and less drag than the aileron that is lowered. The aileron angled downward (the left aileron in this example) produces more drag and more lift, initially yawing the airplane in the opposite direction of your roll.

Its deflection is controlled by a trim wheel or electrical switch in the cockpit, arranged to operate in an instinctive sense
To maintain the primary control surface in its required position, the tab is moved in the opposite direction to the control surface until the tab moment balances the control surface hinge moment
learning.explanation: Trim Tabs (figure 1) A trim tab is a small adjustable surface set into the trailing edge of a main control surface. Its deflection is controlled by a trim wheel or electrical switch in the cockpit, arranged to operate in an instinctive sense. To maintain the primary control surface in its required position, the tab is moved in the opposite direction to the control surface until the tab moment balances the control surface hinge moment. Stabiliser Trim (figure 2) This system of trimming may be used on manually operated and power operated controls. To trim, the tailplane incidence is adjusted by the trim wheel until the tailplane load is equal to the previous elevator balancing load required. Stick force is now zero. The main advantages of a variable incidence (trimming) tailplane are: - The drag is less in the trimmed state as the aerofoil is more streamlined. - Trimming does not reduce the effective range of pitch control as the elevator remains approximately neutral when the aircraft is trimmed. - It is very powerful and gives an increased ability to trim for larger CG and speed range. The disadvantage of a variable incidence (trimming) tailplane is that it is more complex and is heavier than a conventional trim tab system. In this exercise, Figures 1 and 3 refer to trim tabs, and Figures 2 and 4 refer to stabiliser Trim. The least amount of drag would be produced by a stabiliser trim where the position of the elevator is neutral, which, in this case, is Figure 4.

key_points: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement
In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from it's trimmed speed
The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane
learning.explanation: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement. In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from it's trimmed speed. The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane. The position of the CG not only affects the positive longitudinal static stability, it also affects the pitch handling characteristics. When the elevators are deflected, the pitching moment they produce must be greater than the restoring moment of the airplane’s positive longitudinal static stability. An aircraft has higher longitudinal stability with a forward CG (meaning the force and deflection required to make a pitch change is higher), so therefore an aft movement of CG decreases the stability (increases the manoeuvrability), providing the same change in load factor for a smaller control surface deflection.

content.question: To pitch a conventional aeroplane nose up, the pilot applies backpressure on the control column. This moves the elevator relatively..

options.C: upwards, increasing the negative camber of the tailplane and elevator.

key_points: The pilot applies backpressure on the control column, this causes the nose to rise and, if enough thrust is present, the aircraft to climb
The control surface to cause the nose up movement is the elevator
The elevator is positioned behind the Center of Gravity, while the nose is positioned in front of it
learning.explanation: The pilot applies backpressure on the control column, this causes the nose to rise and, if enough thrust is present, the aircraft to climb. The control surface to cause the nose up movement is the elevator. The elevator is positioned behind the Center of Gravity, while the nose is positioned in front of it. Therefore, if the nose rises, the opposite action should happen at the tail. This is done by the elevator generating negative lift (also called downforce). The elevator does this by moving upwards, changing the aerodynamic camber of the tailplane to a negative camber. Whereas positive camber generates positive lift, negative camber generates negative lift. This effect pushes the tail (which is positioned behind the CG) downwards, which has an opposite reaction on the nose (in front of the CG), which comes up.

learning.explanation: Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load. Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls. This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe. To counteract these characteristics and assist the pilot to use the control surfaces correctly it is necessary to have anti-balance tabs fitted. These operate in the opposite sense to the balance tab by deflecting the anti-balance tab in the same direction as that of the primary control surface and increase the aerodynamic loading.
