content.question: Before take-off, extra fuel is added aft of the CG, on an airliner with stabiliser trim. After adjusting the trim for take-off, how will the stabiliser move?

options.A: The stabiliser does not move, but the elevator will be deflected downwards.
options.B: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be lowered.
options.C: The trailing edge of the stabiliser will be raised.
options.D: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be raised.

key_points: An aeroplane is trimmed when it will maintain its attitude and speed without the pilot having to apply any load to the cockpit controls
If it is necessary for a control surface to be deflected to maintain balance of the aircraft, the pilot will need to apply a force to the cockpit control to hold the surface in its deflected position
This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls
learning.explanation: An aeroplane is trimmed when it will maintain its attitude and speed without the pilot having to apply any load to the cockpit controls. If it is necessary for a control surface to be deflected to maintain balance of the aircraft, the pilot will need to apply a force to the cockpit control to hold the surface in its deflected position. This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls. The aircraft may need to be trimmed in pitch as a result of: - changes of speed. - changes of power. - varying CG positions. - changes of configuration. VARIABLE INCIDENCE TAILPLANE The Variable Incidence Horizontal Stabiliser provides pitch trim on most transport category aircraft. Varying the angle of incidence has the same effect as moving the elevator, but is aerodynamically more efficient, particularly at high airspeeds, and can provide a considerable trim range. An actuator near the leading edge varies the angle of incidence of the stabiliser. This normally operates in conjunction with the elevator to produce the least trim drag. The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required. A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the aeroplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude. An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the aeroplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch. The CG must remain within the CG safe envelope at all times to ensure that the aeroplane remains controllable in all phases of flight. The elevator trim or stabiliser trim setting must be preset to a value for take-off and initial climb that will ensure a minimum stick force during this critical stage of flight. In comparison with a correctly balanced aeroplane during take-off, the position of the stabiliser for a nose-light aeroplane requires nose-down trim from an increased stabiliser angle of incidence.

content.question: The pilot's control input in a Fly-By-Wire system is:

options.A: linked by mechanical cables directly to the flight control surface.
options.B: converted into an electrical signal and linked via a computer to the flight control surface.
options.C: linked mechanically to a computer and then to the flight control surface.
options.D: linked by electrical wires directly to the flight control surface.

key_points: Fly by wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly by wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. Advantages of fly by wire Weight reduction, as there is no need for the long and heavy control cables this is a big reduction in the weight of the aircraft. Pilot work load is reduced because the pilot is supported by the computers with automated features like auto trim and turn coordination. Flight envelope protection, which can prevent the pilot from pitching up too much beyond the stalling angle of attack. It can limit the controls in such a way that the airframe will not endure Gforces out of the limits. Disadvantages Reliability, as conventional systems might give some indication of an upcoming failure, a fly by wire system can lose a computer would could result in loss of control. This means there is need for redundancy in the form of additional computers and hydraulic systems.

content.question: What does a fully powered system require compared to a partially-powered system?

options.C: Servo-tab.

key_points: FULLY POWERED SYSTEM A fully powered system means that no control force is felt, since the deflection is done solely by hydraulic pressure
For a fully powered control system, artificial feel unit is needed
Without this system it would be easy to aerodynamically over-stress the aeroplane
learning.explanation: FULLY POWERED SYSTEM A fully powered system means that no control force is felt, since the deflection is done solely by hydraulic pressure. For a fully powered control system, artificial feel unit is needed. Without this system it would be easy to aerodynamically over-stress the aeroplane. POWERED-ASSISTED SYSTEM A power-assisted system is designed so that a part of the control force is felt by the pilot (the rest is done by hydraulic power).

content.question: In general, control forces are reduced by:

options.A: a horn balance, servo tab and spring tab.
options.B: a balance tab, forward shift of the CG and a servo tab.
options.C: a servo tab, spring tab and mass balancing.
options.D: mass balancing, a trim tab and spring tab.

key_points: The primary function of any aerodynamic control surface balancing method is to reduce the force required to operate the control
The most common methods employed to achieve this aim and reduce the maneuver stick force are: the hinge balance
the horn balance
learning.explanation: The primary function of any aerodynamic control surface balancing method is to reduce the force required to operate the control. The most common methods employed to achieve this aim and reduce the maneuver stick force are: the hinge balance. the horn balance. the internal balance (sealed chamber). the balance tab. the spring tab. the servo-tab. Note: "mass balance" is incorrect as it is used to reduce flutter and not stick forces.

content.question: As the CG of an aircraft moves forward from the neutral point, the amount of elevator deflection required to control the aircraft...

options.C: increases.

key_points: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP)
This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating
As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. In this case, if an aircraft is very stable (forward CG), the elevator will have to produce a bigger moment to move the pitch and thus requires a larger deflection

content.question: In a power-assisted flight control system, most of the force is provided by the…

options.C: pilot.

key_points: If the required assistance for the pilot to move the controls cannot be provided by the preceding types of aerodynamic balance, then power assisted, or fully powered controls must be used
The aerodynamic force on the controls will depend on the area of the control surface, its angular displacement, and the IAS
For large and fast aircraft, the resulting aerodynamic force can give hinge moments / stick forces which are too high for easy operation of the controls
learning.explanation: If the required assistance for the pilot to move the controls cannot be provided by the preceding types of aerodynamic balance, then power assisted, or fully powered controls must be used. The aerodynamic force on the controls will depend on the area of the control surface, its angular displacement, and the IAS. For large and fast aircraft, the resulting aerodynamic force can give hinge moments / stick forces which are too high for easy operation of the controls. The pilot will require assistance to move the controls in these conditions, and this can be done either by using (hydraulic) powered flying controls or by using some form of aerodynamic balance.

content.question: In comparison to elevator deflection, all-flying tailplanes require (1) _____ force to change the aircraft's pitch attitude and cause (2) _____ drag.

options.C: (1) less; (2) less

key_points: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions
They also need large control surfaces to be able to control such large aircraft
For these reasons, elevators are often not enough on their own to provide all the pitch trim and pitch control required
learning.explanation: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions. They also need large control surfaces to be able to control such large aircraft. For these reasons, elevators are often not enough on their own to provide all the pitch trim and pitch control required. Some aircraft use a variable incidence horizontal stabiliser and elevators, which just means that the whole tailplane moves in order to trim the aircraft and the elevators are a control surface on the back of this. Some aircraft go even further than this, and have something known as an "all moving tailplane", or "all-flying tailplane", and is also known as a "slab tail". This has no elevator surface at the back, and combines the trim and control inputs into a single movement that the whole tail makes. This is more efficient than using elevators only, as it is a large (full wing) surface making a small change, rather than smaller elevators making a large change, and this not only causes a lot less aerodynamic drag, but also requires less force from the aircraft's hydraulic systems. The reason less force is required to move the all-flying tailplane than elevators is because elevators are hinged at the front, whereas "slab tails" rotate around a point closer to the middle, and therefore the front of the tail helps the movement somewhat. Also, a much smaller movement is required, which does not "fight" the airflow as much, like an elevator does. This is why they may also be used on light aircraft to provide "lighter" stick forces, but on larger aircraft, the hydraulics are doing all the hard work anyway.

content.question: The pilots prepare and trim the aircraft for take-off, setting the trim for a CG position at 24% of the MAC. But due to an error, the real position of the CG is at 12% of the MAC. What could this cause?

options.A: The length of the runway may not be sufficient to take-off.
options.B: Large stick forces are required to achieve rotation.
options.C: Risk of over rotation that can lead to a tail strike.

key_points: When the CG is located further forward than intended, it shifts the aircraft's balance towards the nose
In this case, during takeoff, the aircraft would tend to have a tendency to pitch down, making it harder to rotate and lift off the runway
The pilots would need to apply significant backpressure on the control stick to raise the nose and achieve the desired rotation angle
learning.explanation: When the CG is located further forward than intended, it shifts the aircraft's balance towards the nose. In this case, during takeoff, the aircraft would tend to have a tendency to pitch down, making it harder to rotate and lift off the runway. The pilots would need to apply significant backpressure on the control stick to raise the nose and achieve the desired rotation angle. This would result in large stick forces being required to initiate the rotation. The risk of over rotation and tail strike (option c) would not be a concern in this scenario since the CG is forward rather than aft. The other options, a) and d), are not directly affected by the CG position and are not applicable in this situation. Therefore, if the actual CG position is at 12% (as opposed to 24%) of the MAC, the correct answer would be b) Large stick forces are required to achieve rotation.

content.question: A trim tab is an adjustable surface which can reduce the moment at the hinge line of the main control surface to zero. It can achieve this because its lift force...

options.A: is set far from the hinge line of the main control surface.
options.B: can be deflected through a larger angle compared to the main control surface.
options.C: is controlled from the cockpit just like the main control surface.
options.D: is set close to the hinge line of the main control surface.

key_points: Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection
However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer
There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed
learning.explanation: Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection. However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer. There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed. The variable trim tabs may be manually or electrically controlled. If manually controlled, then trim wheels located on the center console are used. For the elevator trim if the tab is deflected up the cockpit indication is nose-down and if the trim tab is deflected down the cockpit indication is nose-up. To remain in trim and maintain level flight following a deceleration the trimmer control is moved to give a nose-up movement that causes the trim tab to move down, which makes the elevator move up. This does not affect the static longitudinal stability. The moment required to move the primary control surface to the required position (MM) is equal to the force (FM) multiplied by the length of the arm (Am) from the hinge of the elevator to the center of pressure of the elevator main control surface. The same moment can be applied to the elevators by a smaller force (FT) in the opposite direction generated by a trim tab multiplied by the longer arm distance (AT) from the center of pressure of the trim tab to the elevator hinge-line. In other words, (FM × AM) = (FT × AT). The trim tab thereby does the work required to maintain the elevator out of the neutral position and there is no need for any force from the pilot’s controls.

content.question: Generally, ailerons are fitted towards the wing-tips. However, some aeroplanes are fitted with outboard and inboard ailerons. At high flight speeds only the inboard ailerons are used, this is done to...

options.A: reduce the rolling moments which might generate excessive bending forces at their wing root if the outboard ailerons were to be used.
options.B: ensure that the wing does NOT twist through aero elastic effects which would modify the local angle of attack and generate roll reversal.
options.C: reduce the effects of adverse yaw which are greater when using outboard ailerons.
options.D: increase flight control redundancy in the aeroplane’s roll control should the outboard aileron system fail.

key_points: AILERONS The primary effect of ailerons is to provide roll control about the longitudinal axis A downward movement of the aileron causes an increase in the effective angle of attack and a corresponding increase in lift, whilst an upward movement of the aileron causes a reduction in the effective angle of attack and a decrease in lift
The difference in lift between the two wings produces the necessary rolling moment
INBOARD AILERONS Ailerons are normally situated at the wing tips to give the greatest rolling moment for the force produced
learning.explanation: AILERONS The primary effect of ailerons is to provide roll control about the longitudinal axis A downward movement of the aileron causes an increase in the effective angle of attack and a corresponding increase in lift, whilst an upward movement of the aileron causes a reduction in the effective angle of attack and a decrease in lift. The difference in lift between the two wings produces the necessary rolling moment. INBOARD AILERONS Ailerons are normally situated at the wing tips to give the greatest rolling moment for the force produced. However, this means they are also able to generate the maximum twisting loads on the wing. For instance, a down-going aileron will twist the wing tip and decrease wing tip incidence. The wing is not a rigid structure and any twist will cause a decrease of aileron effectiveness. As IAS increases, a down-going aileron will give more wing twist (decreased wing tip incidence). Eventually, an IAS will be reached at which the decrease in tip incidence will give a larger downforce than the upforce produced by the aileron. This is called high speed “aileron reversal”; the wing will go down, rather than up as the pilot intended. To reduce this effect, the ailerons could be mounted further inboard. Unfortunately, this would reduce aileron effectiveness at low speed. Alternatively, two sets of ailerons may be fitted: one set at the wing tips for use only at low speeds when the forces involved are low, and one set inboard for use at high speeds when the forces are greater and could cause greater structural distortion. Outboard (low speed) ailerons are “locked-out” as the flaps retract. At low speed both sets of ailerons work, but at high speed only the inboard ailerons respond to control input.

content.question: The aircraft yaws to the left. This might occur because:

options.C: You roll the left.
options.D: There is increased lift in the right wing.

key_points: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn
As you roll to the right, your airplane may initially yaw to the left
When you roll your airplane to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn. As you roll to the right, your airplane may initially yaw to the left. When you roll your airplane to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down. The right aileron creates less lift and less drag than the aileron that is lowered. The aileron angled downward - the left aileron - produces more drag and more lift, initially yawing the airplane in the opposite direction of your roll.

content.question: A jet transport aircraft is on short final approach when a vehicle enters the runway and they have to go-around. Upon going around, the crew notices that the stabiliser trim has jammed. How will this affect controllability?

options.A: The aircraft will NOT be able to go around, and the crew must land.
options.B: The aircraft will respond less to the elevator in the opposite sense.
options.C: The aircraft's nose will tend to rise as the aircraft accelerates.
options.D: The aircraft's nose will tend to lower as the aircraft accelerates.

key_points: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions

They often use a variable incidence horizontal stabiliser, which just means that the whole tailplane moves in order to trim the aircraft and the elevators are a control surface on the back of this (some aircraft have a "slab tail" design where the elevator and trim are both done by an all-moving tailplane)
If this stabiliser becomes jammed, then the aircraft will remain trimmed for a particular configuration/speed, and can cause serious problems when flying in other configurations/speeds
learning.explanation: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions. They often use a variable incidence horizontal stabiliser, which just means that the whole tailplane moves in order to trim the aircraft and the elevators are a control surface on the back of this (some aircraft have a "slab tail" design where the elevator and trim are both done by an all-moving tailplane). If this stabiliser becomes jammed, then the aircraft will remain trimmed for a particular configuration/speed, and can cause serious problems when flying in other configurations/speeds. In this case, the pilot is trimmed for a low speed (forget flap settings for now because they make things overly complicated but don't change the answer), which means being trimmed for a high angle of attack. In reality, the basis behind trimming is actually quite complicated, but in essence, we trim to balance the aircraft at a particular angle of attack, which equates to a speed (there are a lot of assumptions in that statement but it's fine for this question). When we accelerate from that speed, the aircraft will provide too much lift and pitch up naturally, this is where we would usually begin to trim down to decrease the angle of attack, but without a working trimmer, we have to hold it on the elevator control whilst out of the trimmed condition. Without an elevator, the aircraft will continue to pitch up until it stops accelerating. If there isn't a separate elevator, then the aircraft will have to be trimmed with speed using thrust, faster makes it pitch up, slower makes it pitch down. The aircraft will attempt to hold the same angle of attack, which loosely equates to a speed. It can be flown like this, but it would not be easy. This question seems like there is a separate trimmer to the elevator, so that should not be necessary.

content.question: An aeroplane has a servo tab controlled elevator. What will happen if the elevator jams during flight?

options.A: The servo tab now works as a negative trim tab.
options.C: Pitch control is lost.

key_points: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable
To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function
The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column
learning.explanation: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable. To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function. The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column. There is no direct link between the control column and the primary control surface. The function and operation of the servo-tab is the same as the balance tab and moves the trim tab in the opposite direction to the movement of the primary control surface. However, at low IAS the servo-tab makes the main control surface less effective. The position of a servo-controlled primary control surface cannot be determined until a positive pressure is applied to the servo-tab by the airflow. In flight, if a servo-controlled elevator jams the servo-tab reverses the direction of the pitch control input, because the elevator becomes part of the fixed horizontal stabilizer and the servo-tab now acts as a small elevator because despite its small size it has a longer moment arm than the elevator and consequently generates a large moment. Under normal circumstances an up servo-tab position would drive the elevator to a downward deflection causing the airplane’s nose to go down, but if the elevator is fixed the servo-tab in an up position will cause the airplane’s nose to move up.

content.question: A given aileron deflection affects...

options.A: bank angle and is dependent on TAS
options.B: bank angle and is dependent on IAS
options.C: roll rate and is dependent on TAS
options.D: roll rate and is dependent on IAS

key_points: True airspeed (TAS) depends on air density but IAS does not contain the air density, it is calibrated for ISA
TAS is the speed of the aircraft through the air, and it is the only real aircraft speed that contains air density
If you fly higher, you need higher airspeed to get the same forces on the controls for the same deflection
learning.explanation: True airspeed (TAS) depends on air density but IAS does not contain the air density, it is calibrated for ISA. TAS is the speed of the aircraft through the air, and it is the only real aircraft speed that contains air density. If you fly higher, you need higher airspeed to get the same forces on the controls for the same deflection. However the IAS will be the same as it does not contain the density, but TAS will be higher in reality.

content.question: A last minute change to the weight and balance of an aircraft adds more weight in a forward area. The aircraft remains within limits after the weight addition; what will happen to the stabiliser trim for take-off?

options.A: Set trim nose-down, leading edge up.
options.B: Set trim nose-up, leading edge down.
options.C: Set trim nose-up, leading edge up.
options.D: Set trim nose-down, leading edge down.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.05.08.03.03: Explain the relationship between CG position, take-off trim setting, and stabiliser trim position. Weight and CG location massively affect the handling characteristics of an aircraft. This is why most large jet aircraft calculate different pitch trim settings to use for take-off, depending on the position of the CG and the take-off mass of the aircraft. This is so the pilot can always feel roughly the same force when rotating the aircraft, and in the first phase of flight. If the aircraft has a far forward CG location, the nose will feel heavy to the pilot, so during the setup, the pilots will set a much more nose-up trim setting, so that at rotation, the feeling will be roughly the same. This is exactly what the question is referring to. Extra weight at the front of the aircraft will make the aircraft nose heavy, requiring nose-up stabiliser trim to feel the same. A nose up stabiliser trim is caused by providing extra downforce (or less lift force) on the tail. That is created by setting the horizontal stabiliser at a lower angle, with its leading edge pointing more downwards.

content.question: In the fly-by-wire flight envelope protection system, the protections which can be overridden are:

options.C: Both hard and soft protections.

key_points: There are two main approaches to fly-by-wire systems, namely: Soft protection: Fly-by-wire is used to transmit signals to the hydraulic actuators
The system does not alter the pilot signals or if the signal is modified it can be overrided by the pilot
(Common with Boeing aircraft) Hard protection: Fly-by-wire is used to transmit and transform signals by the flight computers
learning.explanation: There are two main approaches to fly-by-wire systems, namely: Soft protection: Fly-by-wire is used to transmit signals to the hydraulic actuators. The system does not alter the pilot signals or if the signal is modified it can be overrided by the pilot. (Common with Boeing aircraft) Hard protection: Fly-by-wire is used to transmit and transform signals by the flight computers. The pilot does not have full authority (pilot cannot override it) and certain flight envelope protections are installed. (Common with Airbus aircraft)

content.question: Aileron deflection causes a rotation around the longitudinal axis by:

options.A: causing sideslip, which generates a rolling moment.
options.C: changing the wing drag and the two wings therefore produce different lift values resulting in a moment about the longitudinal axis.
options.D: changing the wing camber and the two wings therefore produce different lift values resulting in a moment about the longitudinal axis.

key_points: Ailerons function by altering the camber on each wing: increasing camber and lift on one wing while decreasing them on the other
This difference in lift causes the aircraft to roll, creating a moment around the longitudinal axis
When the aileron is deflected downward, it increases the local camber and, consequently, the angle of attack in that area
learning.explanation: Ailerons function by altering the camber on each wing: increasing camber and lift on one wing while decreasing them on the other. This difference in lift causes the aircraft to roll, creating a moment around the longitudinal axis. When the aileron is deflected downward, it increases the local camber and, consequently, the angle of attack in that area. If you attempt to bank the aircraft when a wing is already near its stalling angle, the down-deflected aileron could cause that wing to stall immediately. This would result in the aircraft rolling in the opposite direction from what was intended.

content.question: Consider a symmetrical wing with a control surface in the trailing edge. When the control surface is deflected downwards, it (1) _____ the camber, producing a force in the (2) _____ direction of the deflection.

options.C: (1) decreases; (2) opposite

key_points: In flight, an aircraft can rotate about any one, or any combination of, its three axes
These axes are at right angles to each other and all pass through the aircraft’s centre of gravity
The moment around an axis is produced by changing the aerodynamic force on the appropriate aerofoil
learning.explanation: In flight, an aircraft can rotate about any one, or any combination of, its three axes. These axes are at right angles to each other and all pass through the aircraft’s centre of gravity. The moment around an axis is produced by changing the aerodynamic force on the appropriate aerofoil. The magnitude of the force is a product of the dynamic pressure (IAS) and the angular displacement of the control surface. Aerodynamic force can be changed by: - adjusting the camber of the aerofoil. - changing the incidence of the aerofoil. - decreasing lift and increasing drag by “spoiling” the airflow. Changing the camber of any aerofoil (wing, tailplane or fin) will change its lift. Deflecting a control surface effectively changes its camber. AILERONS The primary effect of ailerons is to provide roll control about the longitudinal axis A downward movement of the aileron causes an increase in the effective angle of attack and a corresponding increase in lift, whilst an upward movement of the aileron causes a reduction in the effective angle of attack and a decrease in lift. The difference in lift between the two wings produces the necessary rolling moment.

content.question: What is the position of the elevator in relation to the trimmable horizontal stabiliser of a power assisted aeroplane that is in trim?

options.A: The elevator is always deflected slightly downwards in order to have sufficient remaining flare capability.
options.B: The elevator deflection (compared with the stabiliser position) is always zero.
options.C: At a forward CG the elevator is deflected upward and at an aft CG the elevator is deflected downward.
options.D: The position depends on speed, the position of slats and flaps and the position of the centre of gravity.

key_points: Instead of using elevators to change the angle of attack and camber of the tail plane, the whole of the tail plane lifting surface is constructed in such a manner that it has a mutable incidence or changeable angle of attack
This is known as the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS)

The advantages of this tail plane over a conventional fixed tail plane, with an elevator and trim tab, is that the trim is more powerful, it creates less drag, retains full elevator movement at extreme trim angles and is able to cope with a larger range of CG positions than traditional elevator trim tabs
learning.explanation: Instead of using elevators to change the angle of attack and camber of the tail plane, the whole of the tail plane lifting surface is constructed in such a manner that it has a mutable incidence or changeable angle of attack. This is known as the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS). The advantages of this tail plane over a conventional fixed tail plane, with an elevator and trim tab, is that the trim is more powerful, it creates less drag, retains full elevator movement at extreme trim angles and is able to cope with a larger range of CG positions than traditional elevator trim tabs. The angle of incidence of an adjustable stabilizer is controlled by the airplane’s trim system, which alters the jack datum setting. The position of a properly trimmed variable-incidence tail plane depends, most importantly on, the CG position, the airspeed, the thrust setting and on the flap/slat position. When correctly trimmed the elevator angle relative to the horizontal stabilizer is neutral and the stabilized speed is referred to as the ‘trim speed.’ Thus, the trim may be used to set the desired speed without having to hold the elevator out of its trimmed position. A tail-heavy airplane would require the elevator to be deflected downward, which when the variable incidence tail plane is trimmed has no elevator deflection; it is in the neutral position and the leading edge of the adjustable stabilizer is up. If it becomes jammed in the cruise position, when approaching to land select a higher landing speed and/or use a lower flap setting. When trimmed for a forward CG position (nose heavy) the stabilizer leading edge is lower than the trailing edge.

com, so we can correct any differences and verify the answer, thank you! There are two scenarios that this could be

There are two scenarios that this could be. Faulty autopilot or trim runaway. A faulty autopilot would be exactly as it sounds, the autopilot is inputting the incorrect command into the control system, and the feedback loop is not working correctly to fix it. The fix for this situation would be disconnecting the autopilot. Of course, the pilots must then be aware that the trim will be set massively different from normal, so the forces will be high upon autopilot disconnect. The other situation is a trim runaway. It is difficult to tell from the question whether this is the situation or not. A trim runaway is where the electric trim system of an aircraft continues changing the trim angle, without command from the pilots. It could be due to the trims themselves, or the trims commanded by the autopilot. It is then up to the pilot to choose whether to disconnect the autopilot or not, as leaving the autopilot running reduces the forces the pilots have to bear, but disconnecting could fix the problem entirely. We would say that as the aircraft is already struggling to maintain altitude, disconnecting the autopilot is the best bet, and the pilots can switch off the electric trim and use the manual one if the problem has not been fixed.

key_points: The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required
A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the airplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude
An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the airplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch
learning.explanation: The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required. A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the airplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude. An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the airplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch. The CG must always remain within the CG safe envelope to ensure that the airplane remains controllable in all phases of flight. The elevator trim or stabilizer trim setting must be preset to a value for take-off and initial climb that will ensure a minimum stick force during this critical stage of flight. Usually, there is a graph in the airplane performance manual from which the setting appropriate to the total mass and CG position for take-off can be determined. Factors that affect the stabilizer trim position for take-off are: CG position Take-off mass Flap setting In comparison with a correctly balanced airplane during take-off, the position of the stabilizer for a nose-heavy airplane requires nose-up trim from a decreased stabilizer angle of incidence.

key_points: Aileron reversal can occur at high speed when the wing twists as a result of the loads caused by operating the ailerons
In figure 1 the aileron has been deflected downwards to increase lift and raise the wing
Aerodynamic forces act upwards on the aileron, and as this is behind the flexural axis of the wing, it will cause a nose-down twisting moment on the wing structure
learning.explanation: Aileron reversal can occur at high speed when the wing twists as a result of the loads caused by operating the ailerons. In figure 1 the aileron has been deflected downwards to increase lift and raise the wing. Aerodynamic forces act upwards on the aileron, and as this is behind the flexural axis of the wing, it will cause a nose-down twisting moment on the wing structure. This will reduce the angle of attack of the wing which will reduce its lift. If the twisting is sufficient, the loss of lift due to decreased angle of attack will exceed the gain of lift due to increased camber, and the wing will drop instead of lifting.

key_points: With a fully powered flying control the pilot is unaware of the aerodynamic force on the controls, so it is necessary to incorporate “artificial feel" to prevent the aircraft from being overstressed
As shown schematically in the diagram, a device sensitive to dynamic pressure (1⁄2 ρ V2)
Pitot pressure is fed to one side of a chamber and static pressure to the other, which moves a diaphragm under the influence of changing dynamic pressure with airspeed
learning.explanation: With a fully powered flying control the pilot is unaware of the aerodynamic force on the controls, so it is necessary to incorporate “artificial feel" to prevent the aircraft from being overstressed. As shown schematically in the diagram, a device sensitive to dynamic pressure (1⁄2 ρ V2). Pitot pressure is fed to one side of a chamber and static pressure to the other, which moves a diaphragm under the influence of changing dynamic pressure with airspeed. This causes “regulated” hydraulic pressure to provide a resistance or ‘feel’ on the pilot’s input controls proportional to IAS2, just as in a manual control. In addition, stick force should increase as stick displacement increases. An advantage of artificial feel is that it can be configured to provide envelope protection, which prevents the pilot over stressing the aircraft. The Boeing777 fly- by-wire system employs envelope protection. This feature of the artificial-feel system provides increasingly greater force when the aircraft is pushed to its limits.

This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls. A Trimmable Horizontal Stabiliser (THS) enables a larger CG and speed range than a conventional tailplane with stabiliser, elevator and trim tab, because the whole stabiliser may be moved for trimming the aeroplane, instead of a relatively “small” elevator and trim tab only (a larger surface is much more effective). When a trim tab is installed, in this case, it will move down in order to maintain the new elevator deflection. The control column is then held in a more aft position. Remember that the trim tab is deflected in the opposite direction than the elevator. For a trimmable horizontal stabiliser, the whole stabiliser's incidence angle can be changes as trimming. The pilot can control the stabiliser by using the trim wheel. If the linkage is mechanic or power-assisted, the neutral point of the control column changes with trim setting. content.question: Which of the following does the Fly-By-Wire control system have?

options.A: Soft protections that the pilot can override.
options.B: Hard protections that the pilot can override.
options.C: Soft protections that the pilot cant override.
options.D: Hard protections, once exceeded, alternate law takes place.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer
The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made
CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer. The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made. CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly. Flight control surfaces are all : ‐ Electrically-controlled ‐ Hydraulically-actuated. Computers interpret pilot input and move the flight control surfaces, as necessary, to follow their orders. However, when in normal law, regardless of the pilot’s input, the computers will prevent excessive manoeuvres and exceedance of the safe envelope in pitch and roll axis. One of the PF's primary tasks is to maintain the aircraft within the limits of the normal flight envelope. Some circumstances, due to extreme situations or aircraft mishandling, may provoke the violation of these limits. Protections are intended to: - Provide maximum authority to the PF to consistently achieve the best possible aircraft performance in extreme conditions - Reduce the risks of over-controlling, or over-stressing the aircraft - Provide PF with an instinctive and immediate procedure to ensure that the PF achieves the best possible result. The normal law protects the aircraft throughout the flight envelope, as follows: ‐ load factor limitation ‐ pitch attitude protection ‐ high-speed protection. - bank angle protection ‐ high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection One of the hard protections on the Airbus system, in normal law, is the stall protection. Without flight crew input, the F/CTL computers maintain the AoA equal to a defined value. The limits of the hard protection prevent the pilot from exceeding the designed flight envelope of the aircraft. The AoA can be further increased by flight crew input, up to a maximum value. The AoA will not exceed that maximum value, even if the flight crew gently pulls the sidestick all the way back. CONTROL LAWS - RECONFIGURATION LAWS Depending on the failures occurring to the flight control system, or on its peripherals, there are 3 levels of reconfiguration : ‐ Alternate law (There are two levels of alternate law : with and without reduced protections.) ‐ Direct law ‐ Mechanical ALTERNATE LAW - REDUCED PROTECTIONS - Load Factor Limitation - Pitch Attitude Protection - Low Speed Stability (Soft protection) An artificial low speed stability replaces the normal angle-of-attack protection. A gentle progressive nose down signal is introduced, that tends to keep the speed from falling below these values. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, stall warnings are activated at an appropriate margin from the stall condition. - High Speed Stability (Soft protection) Above VMO or MMO, a nose up demand is introduced to avoid an excessive increase in speed. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, the aural overspeed warning remains available.

This is known as the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS). One of the advantages of a trimmable stabilizer is that the elevator will be in line with the stabilizer when the aircraft is in trim. This reduces drag, and maintains full control authority, i.e., full elevator deflection can still be applied in either direction, if required. content.question: Which statement is correct about a spring tab?

options.A: At high IAS it behaves like a fixed extension of the elevator.
options.B: At low IAS it behaves like a servo tab.
options.C: Its main purpose is to increase stick force per g.
options.D: At high IAS it behaves like a servo tab.

key_points: At low airspeeds, for some airplanes, aerodynamic balancing is not considered necessary, however, as the airspeed increases it progressively becomes a necessity because of the increasing aerodynamic load on the main control surface
Towards the leading edge of the primary control top surface is pivoted a lever
The top of the lever is connected to the control column and the balance tab is connected to the same lever just above the pivot
learning.explanation: At low airspeeds, for some airplanes, aerodynamic balancing is not considered necessary, however, as the airspeed increases it progressively becomes a necessity because of the increasing aerodynamic load on the main control surface. Towards the leading edge of the primary control top surface is pivoted a lever. The top of the lever is connected to the control column and the balance tab is connected to the same lever just above the pivot. Thus, movement of the control column is transmitted to the primary control surface but does not directly operate it. To ensure that the balance tab is only effective when it is required, the operating lever of the balance tab system is pivoted through a spring mounted on the elevator main control surface. This is the ‘spring tab.’ When the elevators are operated with at low airspeeds, the control column movement is fed directly to the primary control surface with no deflection of the balance tab so that there is no geometric movement between them. However, at higher speeds, one side of the spring is compressed and changes the geometric position of the balance tab relative to the main elevator control surface. The spring causes the tab to move in the opposite direction to the main control surface at an ever-increasing angle, which is directly proportional to the increasing airspeed. Thus, the spring tab assists the pilot by reducing the stick force required to operate the main control surface to a similar level for all airspeeds. At high IAS, the spring tab behaves like a servo-tab.

content.question: When large transport aeroplanes are flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. What system is fitted to the rudder to prevent this happening?

This may be a single gear change which gives a smaller rudder deflection for full pedal movement above a certain speed (Variable Stop), or a progressive gear change which gives a decreasing rudder deflection with full pedal movement as speed increases (Rudder Ratio).

content.question: Which of the following tabs increases the effectiveness of the whole rudder?

options.C: Trim tab.

key_points: ANTI BALANCE TABS Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load
Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls

learning.explanation: ANTI BALANCE TABS Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load. Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls. This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe. To counteract these characteristics and assist the pilot to use the control surfaces correctly it is necessary to have anti-balance tabs fitted. These operate in the opposite sense to the balance tab by deflecting the anti-balance tab in the same direction as that of the primary control surface and increase the aerodynamic loading. In small aircraft, it increases the control feel, and helps prevent you from over-controlling your aircraft's pitch.

content.question: When aircraft speed increases with no configuration change, main wing downwash will (1) _____ and the negative angle of attack of the tailplane will (2) _____.

options.C: (1) increase; (2) decrease.

key_points: Note: The feedback for this question is incomplete so please let us know in the comments if you see it in the real exam and any differences you can remember, thank you! The forces and effectiveness of the tailplane (horizontal stabiliser) are greatly affected by the effective angle of attack of the oncoming airflow
This is not just the relative airflow around the whole aircraft as this air has been somewhat affected by the main wing ahead
The effective airflow aver the tailplane is mostly determined by the downwash from the wing
learning.explanation: Note: The feedback for this question is incomplete so please let us know in the comments if you see it in the real exam and any differences you can remember, thank you! The forces and effectiveness of the tailplane (horizontal stabiliser) are greatly affected by the effective angle of attack of the oncoming airflow. This is not just the relative airflow around the whole aircraft as this air has been somewhat affected by the main wing ahead. The effective airflow aver the tailplane is mostly determined by the downwash from the wing. The main wing works by deflecting a large mass of air slightly downwards as it leaves the wing, so as the aircraft speeds up, there is greater airflow over the wing and that greater amount of air needs slightly less downwards deflection. As long as the right momentum change occurs, the aircraft will have the same amount of lift to counteract drag. This means that the angle of attack of the main wing is reduced, the coefficient of lift is reduced, etc., but most importantly for this question, the downwash angle is decreased. The tailplane often operates with a completely negative angle of attack, partly from the design and partly from this downwash from the main wing, in order to produce downforce to balance out the aircraft force couples and keep the aircraft nose up. This decrease in downwash means that the airflow arriving at the tailplane is "flatter" than before, i.e. it has less negative angle of attack.

content.question: Consider a modern large aeroplane fitted with a Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system. Following a failure, the Flight Control System Control Laws fall one level to the first level of degradation. What would be one of the most noticeable consequences?

options.A: The autopilot is NOT available, but all protections remain in place.
options.B: The autopilot may or may not be available, depending on the specific failure.
options.C: The autopilot is required to remain available according to airworthiness regulations but, depending on the specific failure, some protections may be lost.
options.D: A reversion to the mechanical back-up mode.

key_points: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system uses computers to process the pilot's/autopilot's flight control inputs and send corresponding electrical signals to the flight control surfaces' actuators

Currently, it is generally accepted there are four levels of service employed within Fly-By-Wire systems; in descending order they are: Under Normal Control Law, normal operation, the computers ensure that flight manoeuvre envelope limits are not exceeded

Under Alternate Control Law, entered into after certain computer failures, the aircraft should handle almost exactly as in Normal control, but some protection features will be lost, including the possibility of losing autopilot function, dependent on the specific failures
learning.explanation: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system uses computers to process the pilot's/autopilot's flight control inputs and send corresponding electrical signals to the flight control surfaces' actuators. Currently, it is generally accepted there are four levels of service employed within Fly-By-Wire systems; in descending order they are: Under Normal Control Law, normal operation, the computers ensure that flight manoeuvre envelope limits are not exceeded. Under Alternate Control Law, entered into after certain computer failures, the aircraft should handle almost exactly as in Normal control, but some protection features will be lost, including the possibility of losing autopilot function, dependent on the specific failures. In Direct Control Law, all protections are lost and flying control input is translated directly into movement of the control surfaces without calculation or correction. The final degradation is Mechanical back-up. The aircraft is flown in pitch through use of the pitch trim wheel and roll by a mechanical connection retained to the rudder pedals (through the secondary effect of yaw). It is designed to allow the pilots to maintain control of the aircraft, while restoring flight control computers, after a complete power interruption. In the event of computer failure on a FBW aircraft, some form of back-up mode is required in the event of total computer failure. For this question, the statement "to the first level of degradation", means degradation to the "Alternate Law", where some protections may be lost.

learning.explanation: When a control surface deflection takes place, the lift of an aerodynamic surface changes, generating more or less lift. This changes the moment from the aerodynamic surface acting on the aircraft, resulting in aircraft pitch, roll or yaw. The effectiveness of movement of these control surfaces increases with airspeed for a certain deflection. This happens because the deflection of the control surface changes the CL for the airfoil on which it operates. The effectiveness of surfaces operates through the lift formula (CL * ½ * ρ * V² * S). So, if CL increases, lift will also increase. In this question we are talking about a constant deflection, so CL will remain stable. Therefore, if we increase speed (v), lift will increase and so does the moment resulting from the control surface, increasing aeroplane manoeuvrability.

content.question: Aeroplane manoeuvrability decreases for a given control surface deflection when:

options.C: flaps are retracted at constant IAS.

key_points: Control surfaces produce lift or drag
Lift and drag increase and decrease with increasing and decreasing speed
Therefore, only small deflections are necessary when flying with high airspeeds and larger deflections at lower speeds
learning.explanation: Control surfaces produce lift or drag. Lift and drag increase and decrease with increasing and decreasing speed. Therefore, only small deflections are necessary when flying with high airspeeds and larger deflections at lower speeds. The lift equation states: LIFT = ½ρV2SCL CL = coefficient of lift. This represents angle of attack of the airfoil and the shape of the airfoil. This described in terms of thickness/chord ratio and a camber and can be altered in flight, for example, by lowering the flaps. ρ = The density of the air. For any given altitude during subsonic flight, the density may be considered to be constant. V2 = The velocity of the aircraft, squared. S = The wing area. The lift formula can also be rearranged and written as: LIFT = q × S × CL (q = dynamic pressure, i.e. ½ρ × V2). In the lift equation all factors except density and speed (TAS) are constant. At higher altitude ρ is reduced; therefore TAS (V) must be increased to maintain the same lift (= weight). Drag equation states that: DRAG = ½ρV2SCD ρ = the mass density of the fluid (rho), V = the velocity of the object relative to the air, S = the reference area, CD = the drag coefficient - a dimensionless constant. The drag formula can be rearranged and written as: DRAG = CD × ½ρ × V2 × S From the drag equation it is clear that drag is directly proportional to the frontal area: if it increases by a factor of e.g. 3 the drag will be increased by the same factor.

content.question: In a sideslip, rudder effectiveness may be reduced. Deflection of which control surface will aid, through secondary or couple aerodynamic effects, the rudder yawing moment?

options.C: Ailerons

learning.explanation: 081.08.02.03.01: Explain: the force on the vertical fin; the fuselage side force due to sideslip (using wing-level method); the use of bank angle to tilt the lift vector (in wing-down method). While the question does not explicitly specify, it is presumed to pertain to asymmetric flight. In this scenario, the live engine generates a yawing moment on the dead engine, necessitating corrective action. The pivotal response involves applying rudder input to counteract the yaw induced by the engine failure. However, employing the rudder creates a sideslip, leading to increased drag. The offset rudder also generates a lateral force, exacerbating the sideslip. To mitigate these effects, banking (ailerons) towards the live engine is recommended. This banking maneuver reduces the required deflection of the rudder to maintain the desired track and minimize drag. It's crucial to note that a maximum banking angle of 5° towards the live engine is specified. This limitation is imposed to prevent larger bank angles, which could significantly diminish the vertical lift component.

learning.explanation: Instead of using elevators to change the angle of attack and camber of the tail plane, the whole of the tail plane lifting surface is constructed in such a manner that it has a mutable incidence or changeable angle of attack. This is known as the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS). The advantages of this tail plane over a conventional fixed tail plane, with an elevator and trim tab, is that the trim is more powerful, it creates less drag, retains full elevator movement at extreme trim angles and is able to cope with a larger range of CG positions than traditional elevator trim tabs. The angle of incidence of an adjustable stabilizer is controlled by the airplane’s trim system, which alters the jack datum setting. The position of a properly trimmed variable-incidence tail plane depends, most importantly on, the CG position, the airspeed, the thrust setting and on the flap/slat position. When correctly trimmed the elevator angle relative to the horizontal stabilizer is neutral and the stabilized speed is referred to as the ‘trim speed.’ Thus, the trim may be used to set the desired speed without having to hold the elevator out of its trimmed position. A tail-heavy airplane would require the elevator to be deflected downward, which when the variable incidence tail plane is trimmed has no elevator deflection; it is in the neutral position and the leading edge of the adjustable stabilizer is up. If it becomes jammed in the cruise position, when approaching to land select a higher landing speed and/or use a lower flap setting. When trimmed for a forward CG position (nose heavy) the stabilizer leading edge is lower than the trailing edge.

options.C: leading edge of the up-going aileron protrudes below the lower surface of the wing, causing more drag.
options.D: leading edge of the down-going aileron protrudes above the upper surface of the wing, causing more drag.

key_points: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases
Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing
These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing
learning.explanation: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases. Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing. These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing. This is adverse yaw, which is particularly significant at low airspeeds because of the large aileron deflection necessary to achieve the same rate of roll as at higher speeds with less deflection. Adverse yaw may be counteracted by any one of the following devices: slot/aileron coupling. spoiler/aileron coupling. differential aileron deflection. rudder/aileron coupling. frise ailerons. To counteract adverse yaw the Frise ailerons are designed so that their leading edge produces sufficient profile drag on the upgoing aileron to equal the induced drag of the down going aileron and thus eliminate adverse yaw.

content.question: On a jet aeroplane (engines mounted below the low wing) the thrust is suddenly increased. Which of these statements is correct about the elevator deflection required to maintain zero pitching moment?

options.A: The amount of elevator deflection is independent of CG location.
options.B: The elevator must be deflected downward.
options.C: No elevator deflection be will required because the thrust line of the engines remains unchanged.
options.D: The elevator must be deflected upwards.

key_points: The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability

If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust)
Creating an unstable situation
learning.explanation: The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. To counteract this, a pitch-down moment must be created. Therefore, the elevator must be deflected downwards. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

content.question: Maximum Operating Speed/Mach Number (VMO/MMO) is _____ the Design Dive Speed/Mach Number (VD/MD) or Flight Demonstrated Design Dive Speed/Mach Number (VDF/MDF).

options.C: less than or equal to

key_points: The question is very simple but includes some sections outside of the syllabus, which we can mostly ignore, as they don't affect the answer
All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds
In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes
learning.explanation: The question is very simple but includes some sections outside of the syllabus, which we can mostly ignore, as they don't affect the answer. All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed. There is also a flight demonstrated design dive speed (VDF) which is a demonstrated speed that the aircraft can handle without associated vibrations, buffet or flutter. It is different from VD but for the purposes of this question we do not need to know any more about it. To keep the aircraft within safe operation, the VMO (maximum operating speed) must be kept below VC. This is still very fast, and should not be exceeded in normal operations. This means that it is always sufficiently less than from VD/MD and VDF/MDF. CS 25.1505 Maximum operating limit speed The maximum operating limit speed (VMO/MMO, airspeed or Mach number, whichever is critical at a particular altitude) is a speed that may not be deliberately exceeded in any regime of flight (climb, cruise, or descent), unless a higher speed is authorised for flight test or pilot training operations. VMO/MMO must be established so that it is not greater than the design cruising speed VC and so that it is sufficiently below VD/MD or VDF/MDF, to make it highly improbable that the latter speeds will be inadvertently exceeded in operations. The speed margin between VMO/MMO and VD/MD or VDF/MDF may not be less than that determined under CS 25.335(b) or found necessary during the flight tests conducted under CS 25.253.

key_points: An aircraft has a limit load factor, which is the rated limit for the maximum G-force the aircraft can pull
It is primarily a structural consideration, and aircraft must be designed to exceed a certain load factor (dependent on the aircraft type) by 50% when new
For CS-25 (large transport aircraft) specifications, the flaps up positive limit load factor is 2
learning.explanation: An aircraft has a limit load factor, which is the rated limit for the maximum G-force the aircraft can pull. It is primarily a structural consideration, and aircraft must be designed to exceed a certain load factor (dependent on the aircraft type) by 50% when new. For CS-25 (large transport aircraft) specifications, the flaps up positive limit load factor is 2.5G, and therefore each aircraft is tested to withstand 150% of this (3.75G) without complete structural failure for the initial aircraft certification. The limit load factor is based on the aircraft's maximum take-off weight (MTOW), and so an aircraft lighter than this would likely be able to withstand greater than this load factor before permanent damage occurs (due to the lower forces on the structure), but this is not allowed, and the limit load factor does NOT change with weight, and should never be exceeded under normal operations.

learning.explanation: This question is ambiguous and the answer depends on the interpretation of the question text. There are two possible scenarios: If the question is referring to different aircraft classes (CS 25 vs CS 23), then a light aircraft (CS 23) has a maximum limiting load factor of 3.8 g, whereas a heavy aircraft (CS 25) has a maximum limiting load factor of 2.5 g. In this case, the heavy aircraft will reach its limiting load at a lower value than that of a lighter aircraft. If the question is referring to the same aircraft with a change in mass (for instance, due to fuel consumption), then the limiting load factor is attained at the same value regardless of mass. This is most likely what the question is referring to. Let's consider the following scenario: A Boeing 737 (CS 25) takes off with a mass of 200 tonnes and is limited to a maximum load factor of 2.5 g, which would create a certain amount of stress on the wings if applied. After several hours and using most of its fuel, the aircraft's mass is reduced to 100 tonnes. Applying 2.5 g at this lower mass would create a lower amount of stress on the wings. In theory, the lighter aircraft could withstand more "g" before the stress reached the same level as during takeoff. However, in practice, a CS25 aircraft is certified to a maximum load factor of 2.5 g regardless of its mass. Therefore, the limiting load factor is still 2.5 g, regardless of the aircraft's current mass. content.question:
Which of these statements about the gust load factor on an aeroplane are correct or incorrect?
I. When the slope of the lift versus angle of attack curve increases, the gust load factor decreases.
II. When the wing loading increases, the gust load factor increases.

options.A: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. The load factor deriving from a gust is determined by the magnitude of the vertical velocity of the gust and the forward speed of the airplane. Vertical gusts will affect the load factor (n) by changing the angle of attack of the wing. For a given gust speed and aircraft TAS, the increment in the load factor depends on the increase in CL per change in angle of attack due to the gust (the slope of the lift curve). If the lift curve has a steep slope, the ‘g’ increment will be greater. Factors which affect the lift curve are aspect ratio and wing sweep. Wings having a low aspect ratio, or sweep, will have a lower lift curve slope, and so will give a smaller increase in ‘g’ when meeting a given gust at a given TAS. Therefore, statement 1 is incorrect. High wing loading reduces the ‘g’ increment in a gust. This is because the lift increment produced is a smaller proportion of the original lift force for the more heavily loaded aircraft. For a given TAS and gust speed, the increase of lift will be proportional to the wing area. Therefore, the increase in load factor is inversely proportional to the wing loading. Wing Loading = Weight/(Wing Area) Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

learning.explanation: Wing flutter is a dynamic instability of an aircraft associated with the interaction of aerodynamic (bending and torsion), elastic, and inertial forces. It is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces which can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure. In flight, an aircraft is supported by its wings and they are bent upwards. When encountering a gust, it will shake the wings up and down. As a result, they will be flapping at a specific frequency. When this vibration is similar to that of the structure of the wing, it will begin to resonate. This resonance will amplify the flutter.

Each type of aircraft has its own specific flight envelope, within which it can be safely operated in accordance with the EASA Certification Specifications. This is represented on a velocity against load factor, or V-n diagram. The high-speed limit for many (but not all) CS-23 aircraft is the never exceed speed (VNE) and is a design reference point for the aircraft beyond which the aircraft must not be flown. It provides a safety margin with the point at which structural damage or failure may occur(VD). VNE is the red radial line at the high speed end of the airspeed indicator. Never Exceed Speed VNE: VNE is set below VD to allow for speed upsets to be recovered before reaching any point of possible damage. VNE equals 0.9 x VD in most cases, but please see the regulation for this below, as there is some "wiggle room" in the regulation that makes things slightly more complex (hence our unhappiness with these options). CS 23.1505 - Airspeed Limitations (a) The never-exceed speed VNE must be established so that it is – (1) Not less than 0.9 times the minimum value of VD allowed under CS 23.335; and (2) Not more than the lesser of – (i) 0.9 VD established under CS 23.335; or (ii) 0.9 times the maximum speed shown under CS 23.251.

content.question: An aircraft is flying in steady, straight and level flight with a Coefficient of Lift of 0.47. Calculate the final load factor if a vertical gust increases the angle of attack by 3°. Consider that a change in 1° of Angle of Attack produces a change in CL of 0.1.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. It can be defined by: load factor(n) = (Lift(L)) / (Weight(W)) In straight and level flight, Lift = Weight, thus n = 1. In this exercise, the increment in CL from a gust will be of 0.1 for every degree of angle of attack impacted by the gust. We also know that the aircraft encounters a gust which increases its angle of attack by 3°. In straight and level flight n = 1 or : n = 0.47 / 0.47 A 3° increase in angle of attack, 3 * 0.1 = 0.3 Will give an increment of 0.3 in the CL : 0.47+0.3 = 0.77 A gust which increases the angle of attack by 3° will increase the load factor to : n = 0.77 / 0.47 ≈ 1.64g
