content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct?
I. A higher limit load factor allows the manufacturer to design for a lower stick force per g.
II. The stick force per g is a limitation on aeroplane's operation, which the pilot can determine from the Aeroplane Flight Manual.

options.A: I. is correct, II. is incorrect.
options.B: I. is correct, II. is correct.
options.C: I. is incorrect, II. is incorrect.
options.D: I. is incorrect, II. is correct.

key_points: MANOEUVRING STABILITY Whenever an aircraft is manoeuvring, acceleration forces act on it (if, for example, the aircraft is pulling out of a dive, its flight path will be curved and the resultant pitching velocity provides aerodynamic damping in pitch due to the downward movement of the tailplane)
The tailplane provides the largest contribution toward damping in pitch, although other aircraft components such as the wings do assist
A graph of stick force versus load factor illustrates the manoeuvring stability of an aircraft
learning.explanation: MANOEUVRING STABILITY Whenever an aircraft is manoeuvring, acceleration forces act on it (if, for example, the aircraft is pulling out of a dive, its flight path will be curved and the resultant pitching velocity provides aerodynamic damping in pitch due to the downward movement of the tailplane). The tailplane provides the largest contribution toward damping in pitch, although other aircraft components such as the wings do assist. A graph of stick force versus load factor illustrates the manoeuvring stability of an aircraft. The gradient of the graph should be positive (with increasing load factor the stick force must also increase). This gradient must not be excessively high or the aircraft would be difficult and tiring to manoeuvre. Conversely, it should not be too low or the stick forces would be too light and the aircraft could be over-stressed. The maximum load factors which must be allowed for during maneuvers are shown in an envelope of load factor against speed (EAS). If a higher limit load factor is set by the manufacturer, there's more margin for the aircraft to be controlled inside the envelope and therefore a lower stick force per g may be set. Statement I is correct. The limit load factors will depend on the design category of the aircraft. For example, the limit load factor for modern high-speed jet transport aircraft is -1.0 g and 2.5 g. This value is stated in the Aircraft Flight Manual to be consulted by the pilot and should bever be exceeded. However, the stick force per g is not listed in the AFM. Statement II is incorrect.

There is no normal requirement for the gear to be operated at high IAS so the retract and extend mechanism together with the attachment points to the structure are sized for the required task

learning.explanation: LANDING GEAR SPEED LIMITATIONS The landing gear will normally be retracted as soon as possible after take-off to reduce drag and increase the climb gradient. There is no normal requirement for the gear to be operated at high IAS so the retract and extend mechanism together with the attachment points to the structure are sized for the required task. LANDING GEAR EXTENDED SPEED - VLE There may be occasions when it is necessary to ferry the aircraft with the gear down, and to do this a higher permissible speed would be convenient. LANDING GEAR OPERATING SPEED - VLO This is the speed at which it is safe both to extend and to retract the landing gear. content.question: An aircraft certified under CS-23 has a VA of 181 kt at a mass of 5.7 t. The value of VA at a mass of 5.5 t is…

key_points: Maneuvering Speed (VA) is the speed at which an airplane will stall before exceeding its maximum load limit
To calculate the VA we multiply the stall speed (VS1) by the square root of the load factor (n)
VA = VS1 x √n VA is just a stalling speed
learning.explanation: Maneuvering Speed (VA) is the speed at which an airplane will stall before exceeding its maximum load limit. To calculate the VA we multiply the stall speed (VS1) by the square root of the load factor (n). VA = VS1 x √n VA is just a stalling speed. Thus, it varies with mass: New VS = Old VS x √Change in mass factor New VA = 181 x √ (5500 / 5700) New VA = 181 x 0.9823 New VA = approx. 178 kt

content.question: For a given gust velocity, by how much would the gust load increase for an aircraft flying at 40000 ft, compared to the same aircraft flying at sea level, if the EAS remains the same? The gust load would increase by...

options.A: zero, there will be no increase at all.
options.C: half as much.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
In a vertical gust the change in angle of attack is proportional to the ratio of TAS/vertical gust velocity
True Airspeed: The speed of the aircraft through the air
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. In a vertical gust the change in angle of attack is proportional to the ratio of TAS/vertical gust velocity. True Airspeed: The speed of the aircraft through the air. TAS = EAS / √σ where, σ is Relative Density. The Airspeed Indicator is calibrated for ‘standard’ sea level density, so it will only read TAS if the density of the air through which the aircraft is flying is 1.225 kg/m3. Thus at 40 000 ft where the ‘standard’ density is one quarter of the sea-level value, to maintain the same EAS the aircraft will have to move through the air twice as fast. As altitude increases the TAS at any given CAS increases, so the effect of a vertical gust decreases. At 40 000 ft ISA for example, the TAS at constant EAS is about twice its sea level value. The upgust will change the direction of the relative undisturbed airflow approaching the wing by roughly half as much.

content.question: An aeroplane maintains straight and level flight at a speed of 1.8 VS. A vertical gust causes a load factor of 1.9. Determine the load factor n caused by the same gust at a speed of 2VS:

options.D: Not relevant. The gust at 1.8 VS would cause a stall.

key_points: An aircraft travelling at a certain speed (Vold) encounters a vertical gust which increases its load factor (nold) to a certain amount
The goal is to compare the effect of the same gust on an aircraft travelling at a different speed (Vnew, in blue) and assessing the resultant load factor (nnew)
Vold = 1
learning.explanation: An aircraft travelling at a certain speed (Vold) encounters a vertical gust which increases its load factor (nold) to a certain amount. The goal is to compare the effect of the same gust on an aircraft travelling at a different speed (Vnew, in blue) and assessing the resultant load factor (nnew). Vold = 1.8VS nold = 1.9g Vnew = 2VS nnew =? The first thing we should do is check if in the first situation the aircraft is stalled, by comparing the two VS0: VS1 = VS0 x √(nold) VS1 = √1.9 x VS0 = 1.38VS0 1.38VS0 < 1.8VS0 Therefore, the aircraft is not stalled! As the aircraft does not stall in the first situation, we can calculate the load factor resulting from the same gust on an aircraft travelling at Vnew using a direct proportion: Vold x (nnew−1) = Vnew x (nold−1) nnew = ((Vnew x (nold−1)) / Vold) +1 nnew = ((2VS x (1.9−1)) / 1.8VS) +1 nnew = 2.00g Encountering the same gust with a speed of 2VS the load factor will be 2.00g. The last step of the exercise is to assess the limiting load factor at which the aircraft would stall and conclude if the new load factor calculated would be reached or the aircraft would stall before that. To do this, let us compare Vnew with the stall speed (VS) and load factor in straight and level flight (n1g): Vnew = VS * √(n1g From here results that our limiting load factor is: n1g = V2new n1g = 4.00g As our limiting load factor is higher than the new. In this case encountering the gust the aircraft would have its load factor increased to 2.00g without stalling.

An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe
VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: This is created from quite old feedback, and the figures are not known/confirmed. We have had to choose some figures to fit an answer, which are unlikely to be the same in the exam! Please send us any further exam feedback you can remember if you get this in your exam, so we can make it more exact, thank you! An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe. VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling. If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling. We can therefore use VA in calculations, as it is the stall speed of an aircraft at it's limit load factor. Stall speed calculations are based on the lift force required by the wings, and that varies with weight and load factor (G-force). The higher the weight, or the higher the load factor, the higher airspeed that is required (more airflow makes the wing able to produce greater forces before stalling). For load factor, the formula is: New VS = VS(1G) x sqrt(load factor) Where VS(1G) is the stall speed at 1G (straight level flight) So for the manoeuvring speed VA = VS(1G) x sqrt(limit load factor) We can then re-arrange this to find the limit load factor if we know the VA and the VS(1G) (which we do in this question). The VS(1G) is given in the question as the bottom of the green arc. (VA / VS(1G))2 = limit load factor Limit load factor = (147/73)2 = 4.06 G

content.question: During cruise Flight, an aircraft encounters severe turbulence. The pilot promptly reduces the airspeed to the recommended rough air speed (VRA). The expected speed variations due to turbulence will:

learning.explanation: THE FLIGHT OPERATING ENVELOPE Each type of aircraft has its own specific flight envelope, within which it can be safely operated in accordance with the EASA Certification Specifications. This is represented on a velocity against load factor, or V-n diagram. The V-n diagram illustrates the limit load factors and limit speeds that, if exceeded, may result in permanent structural damage. The limit loads vary depending on aircraft type, but for transport category aircraft these are generally +2.5g and -1g. At low airspeeds the stall may occur before reaching the limit load factor, but at high airspeeds the limit load factor may be reached before the stall. Gusts also affect the load factor, and the additional acceleration forces (g forces) associated with turbulence can result in structural damage (e.g. an up-gust at high airspeeds). Important reference speeds the pilot should be aware of are VS - Unaccelerated stall speed in the clean configuration VA - Maximum design manoeuvring speed and is the highest speed where the aircraft will stall before it exceeds the maximum load factor

content.question:
A flight instructor is demonstrating stall and stall recovery during a lesson. As a part of the exercise, the instructor demonstrates the use of excessive pitch-down stick input during the initial portion of the recovery. Recovering from the dive, the pilot applies excessive back force on the stick, which forces the aeroplane to enter a secondary (accelerated) stall. Considering the aeroplane limitations given below, what speed range should the aeroplane be operated in order to safely carry out this demonstration?
VS: 45 kt
VA: 100 kt
VNO: 125 kt
VNE: 160 kt.

options.C: 45 kt to 125 kt.

key_points: COLOUR CODING OF THE ASI White arc This arc extends from VSO (stall full flap) to VFE (maximum speed with flaps extended), and marks the flap operating speed range
Green arc This arc extends from VSI (stall clean) to VNO (normal operating speed), and is the normal operating speed range
Yellow This arc extends from VNO to VNE (never exceed speed), and denotes the cautionary speed range
learning.explanation: COLOUR CODING OF THE ASI White arc This arc extends from VSO (stall full flap) to VFE (maximum speed with flaps extended), and marks the flap operating speed range. Green arc This arc extends from VSI (stall clean) to VNO (normal operating speed), and is the normal operating speed range. Yellow This arc extends from VNO to VNE (never exceed speed), and denotes the cautionary speed range. Operations within this speed range should not be carried out except in smooth air. Red Radial line This line marks VNE. MANOEUVERING SPEED (VA) (figure 2) VA - Maximum design manoeuvring speed and is the highest speed where the aircraft will stall before it exceeds the maximum load factor THE STALL The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALL RECOVERY To recover from a stall or prevent a full stall, the angle of attack must be decreased to reduce the adverse pressure gradient. This may consist of merely releasing back pressure, or it may be necessary to smoothly move the pitch control forward, depending on the aircraft design and severity of the stall. Allow airspeed to increase and recover lost altitude with moderate back pressure on the pitch control. Pulling too hard could trigger a secondary stall, or worse, could exceed the limit load factor and damage the aircraft structure. At low airspeeds the stall may occur before reaching the limit load factor. That is why, when pulling from a stall recovery, keeping the speed between VS and VA will allow us to not stall again due to the increased load factor. As angle of attack reduces below the critical angle, the adverse pressure gradient will decrease, airflow will re-attach, and lift and drag will return to their normal values.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.01.03.03: Define ‘VFE’ and describe flap limiting speeds. VFE is the maximum speed to be flown with flaps extended. Flaps are incredibly useful for aircraft to allow for slower take-off and landing, as well as increasing drag for increased control during descent and approach phases of flight, and changing the landing pitch attitude of some aircraft. They do have to sustain some very high aerodynamic loads though, as they stick out into the airstream below the wing, and produce very high forces of lift and drag. The maximum speed for flaps extended (VFE) therefore exists to make sure the pilots do not fly too fast with flaps extended, and cause damage to the flaps or their mechanisms. Some large aircraft actually have systems to reduce the flap extension when these speed limits are broken. In this question then, during the approach phase of flight, the pilots will be wanting to extend flaps in preparation for landing, but if the speed is too high and the pilots extend flaps anyway, they may exceed the new (lower) VFE for the increased flap setting. content.question: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to aircraft certified under CS-23 and CS-25?

options.A: Only jet aeroplanes have a VMO.
options.B: VNE applies to all aircraft with an MTOW less than 5 670 kg.
options.C: VNE only applies to CS-23 aircraft but NOT to CS-25 aircraft.

key_points: Note: You may see this question with VMO or MMO used interchangeably, either can be used, it does not change the answer
Please let us know which you get in the exam, by placing feedback in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions
com, thank you! Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25
learning.explanation: Note: You may see this question with VMO or MMO used interchangeably, either can be used, it does not change the answer. Please let us know which you get in the exam, by placing feedback in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25. CS-23 covers "small aircraft". This includes aircraft with MTOW of 5670 kg or less and a maximum operational passenger seating configuration (MOPSC) of 9 or fewer. CS-23 also covers commuter category aircraft up to 8618 kg MTOW and a MOPSC of 19 or fewer. This means that there are CS-23 aircraft with an MTOW above 5670 kg. CS-25 covers "large aircraft". Specifically, "turbine powered Large Aeroplanes". This includes turboprop aircraft as well as turbojet/turbofan (jet aircraft). There is a difference between the limiting flight airspeeds, VNE and VMO/MMO. Some aircraft (usually smaller, slower aircraft) use VNE - the never exceed speed, and a corresponding VNO, the normal operating speed, which should only be exceeded in smooth air (bottom of the yellow arc). Larger/faster aircraft use VMO/MMO - the maximum operating speed/maximum operating Mach number. This is calculated a little differently to VNE, and is a speed that should not be exceeded during normal operations. An aircraft either has VNE or VMO/MMO, never both. If an aircraft uses VMO, it will also have a corresponding MMO, but this is not mentioned in this question CS-23 aircraft mostly use VNE, but turbine powered aeroplanes and those with a particular design dive speed instead use a VMO/MMO (CS 23.1505). Therefore, CS-23 aircraft can use either VNE or VMO/MMO, depending on the particular aircraft. CS-25 aircraft only use VMO/MMO. Now we have enough information to go through each option: "Only jet aeroplanes have a VMO." No, there are turboprop aircraft within CS-25 (and CS-23) that also have VMO, and even the possibility for piston aircraft to have VMO under CS-23 in some cases (CS 23.1505). "VNE applies to all aircraft with an MTOW less than 5 670 kg." No, there are aircraft under 5 670 kg with more than 9 passenger seats that would be under CS-25 (and therefore have a VMO) and there are also aircraft within CS-23 that use VMO (CS 23.1505). "VNE only applies to CS-23 aircraft but NOT to CS-25 aircraft." Yes, the majority of CS-23 aircraft use a VNE (but not all), and CS-25 aircraft only use VMO, so do not use VNE at all. "VMO only applies to CS-25 aircraft but NOT to CS-23 aircraft." No. Whilst all CS-25 aircraft do use a VMO, so do some aircraft certified under CS-23 (turbines and certain piston aircraft [CS 23.1505])

learning.explanation: All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed.

learning.explanation: Flutter is a phenomenon that can occur when an airfoil is subjected to aerodynamic forces. Flutter is an oscillation caused by interaction of aerodynamic forces, structural elasticity and inertial effects. Flutter happens when the eigenfrequencies of two oscillations move close together so their motions can reinforce themselves mutually. When that happens, then the amplitude will increase with each oscillation, up to a point where the amplitude is big enough to break things. Flutter is a very dangerous condition; if it is not stopped, it can cause structural failure and potentially lead to a fatal accident. There are four ways to stop flutter. Limit the flight envelope; immediately leave the speed at which flutter is possible Increase damping; this can be done by for instance adding some friction Increase stiffness; this reduces eigenfrequencies which makes flutter less likely Reduce mass; If a wing is made lighter, the eigenfrequency will move up, increasing flutter speeds.

content.question: Which of the following statements best describes VA?

It is better depicted on a diagram of speed vs load factor (V - n diagram)
The aircraft has a limiting load factor, an amount of acceleration that it can take without permanently damaging the airframe
learning.explanation: VA is the design manoeuvring speed of an aircraft. It is better depicted on a diagram of speed vs load factor (V - n diagram). The aircraft has a limiting load factor, an amount of acceleration that it can take without permanently damaging the airframe. Every aircraft also has a stalling curve, which dictates at what speed the aircraft will stall, when pulling a certain load factor. Put these two together on a diagram and you can see the V - n envelope of the aircraft, how fast we can fly and how many Gs we can pull at a particular speed. VA sits around where the positive stall curve touches the limit load factor. It dictates the point where you can pull the controls as hard as you want, and just as you reach the limit load factor (structural damage point), the aircraft will then stall, removing the chance of structural damage. Any slower and you will stall first, and any faster, and you could permanently damage the airframe. It is not always perfectly on that corner of the diagram, but that is past the scope of this question To look at all the options "The speed for maximum gust velocity." No. The speed for maximum gust velocity is VB, and occurs just above the VA. It is the speed that the aircraft is certified to handle the highest level of gusts (66 fps). "A specifically designated speed to use when penetrating turbulence." The turbulence penetration speed is actually VB also, where the strongest gusts can be handled by the aircraft without stalling or damage occurring. "A speed chosen by the manufacturer for evaluating performance criteria." There are many different speed to evaluate performance criteria with, but they would never use VA, as it is not usually anywhere near speeds such as best range, minimum drag, etc. "The design manoeuvring speed, at or near which rapid, full control reversal should be avoided due to risk of damage to aircraft." Whilst the wording is (intentionally) poor for this option, it is the only one left. We believe that the "control reversal" would just mean going from one full deflection to the other side full deflection. That is really not advisable at any speed, but at and above VA would cause damage to the aircraft. Even just below VA, full control deflection from no deflection is fine (though you may stall), but reversal is not accounted for in the regulations, so in reality the examiner can say what they like to try and confuse you. This is the only remaining option, and correctly stated that it is the design manoeuvring speed, so we are happy to agree that it is most correct.

content.question: CS23 and CS25 specify the requirements for an aircraft's design manoeuvring speed (VA). Given that VA is an equivalent airspeed (EAS), it remains relevant for aeroplanes with conventional flight controls, however its value may become unreliable at high altitudes as…

options.A: airspeed indication is based on a Mach number at high altitude, making VA as an EAS irrelevant.
options.B: higher stall speed and low control forces make it easier to produce a high load factor at high altitudes.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.02.02.03: Explain why VA loses significance at higher altitude. Manoeuvring speed (VA) is defined as the calibrated airspeed (CAS) below which the aircraft will stall before the onset of structural damage or aerodynamic buffeting occurs. It is a function of the aircraft's weight, altitude, and the configuration of the aircraft (flap and landing gear positions). VA is calculated based on EAS, which is the airspeed corrected for instrument and position errors. When jet transports cruise at high altitude, the significance of manoeuvring speed (VA) diminishes since it is not possible to achieve 2.5 g, or similar load factors, at high altitude. Consequently, when a single VA is published, it only applies to low-level flight. As altitude increases, the values of equivalent airspeed (EAS) that correspond to the same Mach numbers increase. The increase in Mach number results in a reduction in CLMAX, and the stall limit curves become shallower, causing both VS1 and VA to occur at higher EAS values. The increased stall speed (VS) means that the low altitude VA is around the low-speed stall at high altitude. Therefore, the option "higher stall speed and low control forces make it easier to produce a high load factor at high altitudes." is more likely correct, as flying the low altitude VA at high altitudes may result in a low-speed stall of a typical jet aircraft rather than a shock stall. If the control surface CG is behind the hinge line, inertia will cause the surface to oscillate about its hinge line
The oscillations can be divergent and cause structural failure
learning.explanation: Flutter is an oscillation of the control surface which can occur due to the bending and twisting of the structure under load. If the control surface CG is behind the hinge line, inertia will cause the surface to oscillate about its hinge line. The oscillations can be divergent and cause structural failure. Flutter involves: - aerodynamic forces. - inertia forces. - the elastic properties of a surface. An aircraft is subject to many aerodynamic excitations (gusts, control inputs, etc.) and the aerodynamic forces at various speeds have characteristic properties for rate of change of force and moment. The interaction of the aerofoil mass and the aerodynamic load imposed on the aerofoil causes distortion by bending and torsion of the structure that can result in a violent vibration in the resonance frequency, which if excessive can cause structural failure. This is ‘flutter’ and the aeroelastic coupling will affect its characteristics. The risk of experiencing flutter increases with IAS. CONTROL SURFACE FLUTTER Control surface flutter can develop as a result of an oscillation of the control surface coupled with an oscillation in bending or twisting of the wing, tailplane or fin. A control surface oscillation can result from backlash (free play) in the control system or from a disturbance (gust). MASS BALANCE Flutter may be prevented by adding weight to the control surface in front of the hinge line. This brings the centre of gravity of the control forward to a position on, or slightly in front of the hinge, but always to the point required by the designers. This reduces the inertia moments about the hinge and prevents flutter developing.

content.question: A light aircraft with mechanical flight controls occasionally experiences uncomfortable pitch oscillations after encountering normal turbulence. The pilot does not note any such oscillations when cruising in smooth air at normal cruising speed, but does notice some excessive slack or play in the elevator linkages after the flight. What potential hazards could this situation cause if not addressed by maintenance?

options.A: This phugoid-type oscillation is likely to increase in magnitude and the aeroplane may enter a stall or encounter an overspeed situation if the oscillation worsens.
options.B: A poorly balanced control surface is creating excessive restoring forces and this short-period motion may cause excessive stress on the airframe.
options.C: The flutter may gradually worsen, and the elevator may vibrate so vigorously that it comes off the hinges and separates from the aeroplane in flight.
options.D: Compared to a phugoid, the short period motion leads to a change in pitch and speed, which, if NOT corrected, may lead to a stall or overspeed situation.

key_points: NOTE: We have had conflicting feedback about this question
The current answer is the one we believe to be most correct, but we are seeing some possible different answers with different authorities
We are in need of more feedback about this one, so please send us anything you can remember from the exam via the comments, the feedback section of the website, or by email to info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: NOTE: We have had conflicting feedback about this question. The current answer is the one we believe to be most correct, but we are seeing some possible different answers with different authorities. We are in need of more feedback about this one, so please send us anything you can remember from the exam via the comments, the feedback section of the website, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct or not. Authority Reported Answer Hungary Not C Poland B Austro Not D We would say if your country is not Hungary or Poland, go for C. FLUTTER Flutter occurs because a wing (or other aerodynamic surface) is not perfectly stiff, and will bend and twist under high aerodynamic loads. The control surfaces can cause a cyclic movement where the wing moves but the control surface "lags behind", creating an even larger force on the wing. The wing will then do the same thing in the opposite direction, and at certain frequencies can build up to a large, short term oscillation that can cause significant damage ton the aircraft. The risk of experiencing flutter increases with IAS. A control surface oscillation can also be intensified or created by any slack (free play) in the control lines, where the control surface can move freely without pilot input. This means that small disturbances such as turbulence could cause un-commanded control surface movements, which then begin a period of flutter, as eluded to in the question. To go through the options: "This phugoid-type oscillation is likely to increase in magnitude and the aeroplane may enter a stall or encounter an overspeed situation if the oscillation worsens." It is not a phugoid type oscillation being described, as a phugoid has a greater time period than this short interval flutter. "A poorly balanced control surface is creating excessive restoring forces and this short-period motion may cause excessive stress on the airframe." The control surface is not necessarily poorly balanced; the cause of the flutter is the free play in the control lines, so we would say this is not correct. However, the rest of the option is correct, so it's not far off. "The flutter may gradually worsen, and the elevator may vibrate so vigorously that it comes off the hinges and separates from the aeroplane in flight." We believe this is fully correct. The free play in the control lines can cause this kind of response. "Compared to a phugoid, the short period motion leads to a change in pitch and speed, which, if NOT corrected, may lead to a stall or overspeed situation." For a while, the Polish ULC considered this to be correct (we believe), but recent feedback indicates they no longer do. The short period motion doesn't really cause large speed changes (that would be a phugoid) and therefore it is not very likely to cause a stall or overspeed situation.

content.question:
The VA speed of a light aircraft is 133 kt. Determine the aircraft's limit load factor, given the following information from the airspeed indicator.
Green arc: 73 kt - 177 kt
White arc: 53 kt - 104 kt
VNE: 185 kt

key_points: An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe
VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling
If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling
learning.explanation: An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe. VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling. If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling. We can therefore use VA in calculations, as it is the stall speed of an aircraft at it's limit load factor. Stall speed calculations are based on the lift force required by the wings, and that varies with weight and load factor (G-force). The higher the weight, or the higher the load factor, the higher airspeed that is required (more airflow makes the wing able to produce greater forces before stalling). For load factor, the formula is: New VS = VS(1G) x sqrt(load factor) Where VS(1G) is the stall speed at 1G (straight level flight) So for the manoeuvring speed VA = VS(1G) x sqrt(limit load factor) We can then re-arrange this to find the limit load factor if we know the VA and the VS(1G) (which we do in this question). The VS(1G) is given in the question as the bottom of the green arc. (VA / VS(1G))2 = limit load factor Limit load factor = (133/73)2 = 3.3 G

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the speeds VMO and VC?

options.A: VMO must be equal to VC.
options.B: VMO must be equal to or greater than VC.
options.C: VMO must NOT be greater than VC.
options.D: VMO must NOT be greater than 0.8 x VC.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.02.01.05: Describe the relationship between VMO or VNE and VC. All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed. To keep the aircraft within safe operation, the VMO (maximum operating speed) must be kept below VC. This is still very fast, and should not be exceeded in normal operations.

learning.explanation: Load Factor is the ratio of the weight of an aircraft to the load imposed by lift: Load Factor = Lift / Weight Lift is propotional to V2: L= CL × ½ rho × V2 × S Therefore, n is proportional to V2. content.question: The lift coefficient (CL) of an aeroplane in steady horizontal flight is 0.35. An increase in angle of attack of 1 degree would increase CL by 0.079. If a vertical gust instantly changes the angle of attack by 2 degrees, the load factor will be:

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. It can be defined by: load factor(n) = (Lift(L))/(Weight(W)) In straight and level flight, Lift = Weight, thus n = 1. In this exercise, the increment in CL from a gust will be of 0.079 for every degree of angle of attack impacted by the gust. We also know that the aircraft encounters a gust which increases its angle of attack by 2°. In straight and level flight n = 1 or: n = 0.35/0.35 A 2° increase in angle of attack, 2*0.079 = 0.158 Will give an increment of 0.45 in the CL: 0.35+0.158 = 0.508 A gust which increases the angle of attack by 2° will increase the load factor to: n = 0.508/0.35 ≈ 1.45 g

options.B: Sustain a positive normal acceleration of 0.3 g Without experiencing either low or high speed buffet.

learning.explanation: This is a poorly worded question. In straight and level flight, the aircraft experiences a load factor of 1 (1 g). The aircraft would be able to withstand a positive normal acceleration of 0.3 g, which totals the buffet margin of 1.3 g. “performs a level turn with 45 of bank without experiencing low speed buffet” Incorrect. Load factor = 1 /cos (bank angle) Load factor = 1 / cos (45º) = 1.41 g 1.41 g exceeds the buffet margin (1.3 g).

content.question:
Which of these statements about the gust load factor on an aeroplane are correct or incorrect?
I. When the mass decreases, the gust load factor increases.
II. When the altitude increases, the gust load factor increases.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. The load factor deriving from a gust is determined by the magnitude of the vertical velocity of the gust and the forward speed of the airplane. High wing loading reduces the ‘g’ increment in a gust. This is because the lift increment produced is a smaller proportion of the original lift force for the more heavily loaded aircraft. For a given TAS and gust speed, the increase of lift will be proportional to the wing area. Therefore, the increase in load factor is inversely proportional to the wing loading. WingLoading = Weight/(WingArea) Decreasing mass, decreases wing loading which increases load factor. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. With increasing altitude, density decreases and any aerodynamic force resulting from a gust will be smaller. Thus, when comparing two aircraft flying at different altitudes, the one flying in thinner air (higher altitude) will experience a decreased increment in load factor following a gust. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: What speed will be limiting with a descent at constant mach?

options.C: VS

key_points: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high
At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder
Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level
learning.explanation: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high. At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder. Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level. The result of this is that, as you climb, the maximum speed is controlled at low level by CAS and VMO, and at altitude you reach your limiting Mach number MMO, before you reach VMO and therefore your maximum speed is controlled by MMO. In the descent the reverse is true. Your maximum speed is controlled by MMO first, and then by VMO at lower altitudes. Alternatively, LSS increases during the descent, due to the rising temperature. Therefore, TAS must increase during descent to maintain constant Mach No. IAS is also increasing and will eventually reach its limit. VMO ("max operating") is the term for the maximum certified IAS. NOTE: You can also advice the ECTM lines to show that IAS increases with constant Mach.

VMO is the maximum operating IAS and MMO is the maximum operating Mach number
learning.explanation: According to CS 25.1505, VMO/MMO is the maximum operating IAS (or Mach number, whichever is critical at a particular altitude), which must not be deliberately exceeded in any flight condition, is referred to as VMO/MMO. VMO is the maximum operating IAS and MMO is the maximum operating Mach number. This speed is that which, allowing for moderate upsets ensures the aircraft will remain free from buffet or other undesirable flying qualities associated with compressibility. It must not exceed VC. When climbing at VMO, the TAS and the Mach number are increasing, so care must be taken to ensure that MMO is not exceeded. Conversely, when descending at MMO, the TAS and IAS increase, and care must be taken not to exceed VMO.

learning.explanation: Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25. CS-23 covers "small aircraft". CS-23 also covers commuter category aircraft up to 8618 kg MTOW and a MOPSC of 19 or fewer. This means that there are CS-23 aircraft with an MTOW above 5670 kg. CS-25 covers "large aircraft". Specifically, "turbine powered Large Aeroplanes". This includes turboprop aircraft as well as turbojet/turbofan (jet aircraft). There is a difference between the limiting flight airspeeds, VNE and VMO/MMO. Some aircraft (usually smaller, slower aircraft) use VNE - the never exceed speed, and a corresponding VNO, the normal operating speed, which should only be exceeded in smooth air (bottom of the yellow arc). Larger/faster aircraft use VMO/MMO - the maximum operating speed/maximum operating Mach number. This is calculated a little differently to VNE, and is a speed that should not be exceeded during normal operations. An aircraft either has VNE or VMO/MMO, never both. If an aircraft uses VMO, it will also have a corresponding MMO, but this is not mentioned in this question CS-23 aircraft mostly use VNE, but turbine powered aeroplanes and those with a particular design dive speed instead use a VMO/MMO (CS 23.1505). Therefore, CS-23 aircraft can use either VNE or VMO/MMO, depending on the particular aircraft. CS-25 aircraft only use VMO/MMO.

key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin. The camber of an airfoil can be increased with the use of flaps. The end of the wing reaches out and/or downwards, changing the side profile of the wing and moving the CP aft, resulting in a nose down pitching moment. This generates a higher value of CL at the same Angle of Attack. Therefore if flaps are being retracted, the Angle of Attack should be increased.

Refer to figure.
Which of the figures shows the change in the total drag graph when density altitude is decreased?

options.C: Figure 3

key_points: When density altitude decreases, the air gets "thicker", meaning that there are more air particles per cubic metre, and therefore more air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would increase lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude decreases, the air gets "thicker", meaning that there are more air particles per cubic metre, and therefore more air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would increase lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but descend in the atmosphere, the higher air density means that we have to fly slower to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is a decrease in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with decreased altitude. As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with a decrease in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the left, due to the decreased TAS for the same IAS at lower altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 2, moving to the left.

learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The feedback for this question is old and has not been verified for over a year. Given other questions in the database which have been confirmed, we have decided to change the options to make one "actually correct", rather than the very questionable previous options, which were never fully verified. This question could have even been removed from EASA's database by now, but we also cannot guarantee that. Please let us know in the comments if you see this question in the real exam, and anything you can remember from it. BACKGROUND INFORMATION Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect of spoilers on the critical angle of attack is much more complex (and explained where necessary in different questions), and unpredictable, but EASA appear to say that it increases with spoiler deployment (opposite to how it decreases when trailing edge flaps are deployed). As far as we are aware, it could actually increase or decrease slightly in real life, dependent on the wing, spoiler size and location, and particularly the amount of spoiler extension. For this question though, mercifully, the answer remains the same. ANSWERING THE QUESTION The question asks about the angle of attack of the wing. When spoilers are extended, the lift decreases, so without any change to the angle of attack, then the aircraft will no longer be in equilibrium, so in reality, to counteract weight, the angle of attack of the wing has to increase. This agrees with our experience of flying jets, in when we extend spoilers, the aircraft pitches up slightly. The margin to the stall is a very vague term, as it could mean the difference between current speed and stall speed, but it is more likely to mean in terms of angle of attack, and in this case, would probably be the difference between the aircraft's current angle of attack and the critical angle of attack (AoA). When spoilers are extended, the actual AoA is forced to increase to maintain the flight path, and the critical angle of attack will either decrease slightly (according to some other sources) or increase slightly (according to EASA's other questions), but either way, the increase in current AoA will likely be much greater, so the margin to stall will decrease.

learning.explanation: When an aircraft flies close to the ground, the downwash of air causing induced drag has nowhere to go, it is stopped by the fixed ground beneath. Therefore, being close to the ground decreases downwash and decreases induced drag. This is called ground effect. Ground effect increases as an aircraft flies closer to the ground, so the lowest height would give the lowest induced drag. Obviously then, the highest induced drag would occur when at the greatest height above the ground. Ground effect is usually cited as taking effect at approximately half the wingspan of height (which would be 30 ft here), as that is when it becomes significant and noticeable, but as with everything in aerodynamics, it is not a binary effect (on or off), it is a gradual change, so the correct answer here is simply the greatest height.

learning.explanation: The lift coefficient is defined as: CL = L/QS Where "L" is the lift force, "S" the area of the wing and "Q" is the dynamic pressure (1⁄2ρ V2). CL = the Coefficient of Lift, or the product of aerofoil design (shape) and angle of attack, or relative pressure distribution. In other words, its ability to deflect air, so this can vary between aerofoils. The coefficient will be maximum at, or just before, the stall, which you can see from the formula - if CL increases on one side, the other side (L) will also increase, until lift can no longer be produced. Similarly, reducing speed (V) decreases lift. Thus, to keep the same lift, you must change the angle of attack (CL) if you change speed, and vice versa.

Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above and left of the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below and right of the origin.

Which of these statements about a steady subsonic flow are correct or incorrect?

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. As an airfoil (wing) moves through the air, varying changes in velocity occur on its surfaces. Air particles move around it in specific trajectories. These trajectories are called streamlines. Diverging streamlines mean a decrease in airspeed. Converging streamlines imply an increase in airspeed. In Conclusion: With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). If dynamic pressure decreases, static pressure increases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

content.question: The value of the induced drag of an aeroplane in straight and level flight at constant mass varies linearly with:

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together

learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V2) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

content.question: Consider an aircraft flying at exactly the critical angle of attack of the main wing. If all other parameters remain the same, when the wing spoilers are extended, the wing will...

options.B: stall, because its critical angle of attack will decrease.

key_points: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons
They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift
(If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions)
learning.explanation: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the lift of the wing greatly, with an unknown effect on the critical AoA Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but it appears that EASA have published other questions where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here. A big consideration for this question is the scenario. We are at the critical AoA and we raise the speedbrakes. Of course, we will begin to descend as the drag increases, unless we add thrust. if we don't do either of these things then the aircraft will quickly stall, but initially, assuming the angle of attack remains constant, the speedbrake extension should slightly delay the stall to a higher AoA.

content.question: Which statement concerning the local flow pattern around a wing is correct?

options.A: By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wing tip vortices is reduced which in turn reduces induced drag.

" Correct
Winglets are small vertical aerofoils that are integrated into the wingtip
learning.explanation: "By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wingtip vortices is reduced, which in turn reduces induced drag." Correct. Winglets are small vertical aerofoils that are integrated into the wingtip. These generate a slight forward force and disrupt the airflow from the lower to the upper surface of the wing, diminishing the intensity of the wingtip vortex. Both effects contribute to a reduction in induced drag. Let's examine the remaining options and discuss why they are incorrect: "Slat extension, at a constant angle of attack and normal extension speeds, will increase the lift coefficient, which will also increase the induced drag coefficient." Incorrect. At a constant aircraft angle of attack, the extension of slats decreases the angle of attack on the specific wing section, preventing an increase in the lift coefficient (CL). The advantage of slats becomes evident when the aircraft's angle of attack is subsequently increased. "Sweepback reduces drag since, compared with a straight wing of equal area, the span increases." Incorrect. Sweepback actually reduces the wingspan, thereby lowering the aspect ratio and increasing induced drag. "Vortex generators on the wing partially block the spanwise flow over the wing, leading to a reduction in induced drag." Incorrect. Vortex generators are designed to energize the boundary layer, but they typically contribute to increased drag rather than inducing a reduction in induced drag.

content.question: Bernoulli’s equation can be written as:(pt = total pressure, ps = static pressure, q = dynamic pressure)

key_points: A venturi works on the principle of pressure, speed and airflow
Air comes in under constant pressure (which we will call X from this point onwards) and is directed through the tube
At a certain point in time, the tube starts becoming tighter
learning.explanation: A venturi works on the principle of pressure, speed and airflow. Air comes in under constant pressure (which we will call X from this point onwards) and is directed through the tube. At a certain point in time, the tube starts becoming tighter. However, the same amount of air still has to travel through this (now tighter) tube (we call this airflow Y). It does so by flowing faster than before. This increased airspeed creates a lower pressure at the tighter part of the venturi, while the wider part still has its original pressure and airspeed. After the tightening, the tube becomes wider again and the air returns to its original static pressure and airspeed (airflow Z). It now has the properties of airflow X again. Before the venturi (airflow X) Static Pressure normal Speed of the airflow normal In the throat (airflow Y) Total pressure same as airflow X and Z Static Pressure low Speed of the airflow increased After the venturi (airflow Z) Static Pressure normal Speed of the airflow normal The venturi works on Bernoulli’s principle. Bernoulli’s principle states that in increase in speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in the fluid’s static pressure. The formula for this principle = Total pressure = static pressure + dynamic pressure. If airspeed increases, the static pressure decreases and dynamic pressure increases, keeping total pressure the same.

learning.explanation: The lift curve, depicted as CL-α, illustrates the lift coefficient (CL) relative to the angle of attack (α) for an aerofoil section. The section is symmetrical because no lift is produced at zero angle of attack. This graphical representation serves as a useful tool for understanding different aircraft configurations. As the angle of attack increases, the lift coefficient rises until reaching its maximum value (CLMAX), corresponding to the critical angle of attack. To generate a constant lift force, any change in dynamic pressure must be accompanied by a change in angle of attack as long as CL is less than CLMAX. CL greater than CLMAX is not possible. This phenomenon is called ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the presence of the nearby ground alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Downwash decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: Lift decreases (if AoA remains constant). The effective angle of attack (αe) decreases. The induced angle of attack (αi) increases. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. content.question: When comparing the effectiveness of leading edge (LE) flaps and trailing edge (TE) flaps in reducing an aircraft's stall speed, which statement is correct?

options.A: Leading edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than trailing edge flaps because they enhance the wing’s curvature, increasing lift at lower speeds.
options.B: Trailing edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than leading edge flaps by increasing the wing area and camber, enhancing lift.
options.C: Both leading edge and trailing edge flaps have the same effect on reducing stall speed by equally increasing the wing's lift capabilities.
options.D: Neither leading edge nor trailing edge flaps significantly reduce the stall speed; they primarily affect the aircraft's drag.

key_points: Important Note: This was fed back to us without the correct answer being known
In this form, the options are quite vague and we could discuss which is correct for a long time and likely never reach an answer
Therefore, we have used our experience with the authorities to give our "best guess" of their correct answer
learning.explanation: Important Note: This was fed back to us without the correct answer being known. In this form, the options are quite vague and we could discuss which is correct for a long time and likely never reach an answer. Therefore, we have used our experience with the authorities to give our "best guess" of their correct answer. Obviously, the question could well be better worded in the real exam and with good knowledge of this subject, would likely be much easier to answer. Please do let us know if you see this question in the exam, any differences you noticed from our version, and if you have any idea of the correct answer with your exam authority, thank you! Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and improve slow flying characteristics. There are both leading edge devices (LE flaps, kreuger flaps and slats) and trailing edge high lift devices (TE flaps of many kinds). Their primary purpose is to allow the aircraft to fly slower, and they do this by increasing the CLMAX of the wings, so that the lift will be enough to counteract weight, even at lower airspeeds. The greater the CLMAX becomes, the lower the stall speed. Secondary effects are increased drag and a change to the wing's chord line and angle of incidence, allowing the aircraft to fly with different pitch attitudes, which can be useful for pilot vision during landing. Let's go through the options now. "Leading edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than trailing edge flaps because they enhance the wing’s curvature, increasing lift at lower speeds." This is not strictly true. Whilst leading edge flaps do enhance the wing's curvature, so do trailing edge flaps, and they both increase the maximum available lift at all speeds. "Trailing edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than leading edge flaps by increasing the wing area and camber, enhancing lift." This is also very difficult to justify, as their increase in CLMAX depends on the TE/LE flaps used and to what degree. Also, not all flaps increase the wing area, only fowler flaps and some variations upon them. Again, TE and LE flaps both increase CLMAX. "Both leading edge and trailing edge flaps have the same effect on reducing stall speed by equally increasing the wing's lift capabilities." For us, this seems most likely to be correct. They both reduce the stall speed by increasing the lifting capability of the wing, allowing the aircraft to fly slower before stalling. "Equally" is a bad word to use though, as they could definitely have a different amount of effect, but it is not for us to say if they do, or which is most "useful". "Neither leading edge nor trailing edge flaps significantly reduce the stall speed; they primarily affect the aircraft's drag." Obviously incorrect, as they both do significantly reduce the stall speed.

content.question: Increasing the aspect ratio of a wing:

options.C: increases induced drag.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional.

At the same time, we want good performance to climb out clear of obstacles

learning.explanation: Lets consider both the take off and landing situations: Take off and climb – The aircraft will be flying close to its stall speed, so we want to increase our maximum angle of attack and therefore have a bigger margin of safety in case of windshear or engine failures. At the same time, we want good performance to climb out clear of obstacles. Since the climb angle is based on thrust and drag: Sin (γ) = (T – D) / W We know that we need to minimize drag as much as possible to get the best climb performance. Therefore lower flaps will be used. High flaps setting usually provide only a slight increase in lift whilst adding a large amount of drag. Approach and landing – The aircraft will be flying again at slow speeds, therefore to increase the safety margin we want a higher CLMAX and therefore a slower stall speed. Secondly, we are in a descent, therefore we can afford to have much more drag than during the departure. Therefore we use a large flap setting which will also create high levels of drag.

key_points: Flaps are called high-lift devices, and are primarily used to allow an aircraft to fly slower without stalling, useful for take-off and landing
Their other uses are for increased drag; modern jet aeroplanes are particularly "slippery" these days, and sometimes struggle to lose energy, so flaps can be used to help with this

learning.explanation: Flaps are called high-lift devices, and are primarily used to allow an aircraft to fly slower without stalling, useful for take-off and landing. Their other uses are for increased drag; modern jet aeroplanes are particularly "slippery" these days, and sometimes struggle to lose energy, so flaps can be used to help with this. Flaps also change the chord line of the wing, allowing a more nose-down attitude for better pilot visibility and easier landings. Flaps increase lift by increasing the camber of the wing, and often also increasing the wing area, depending on the style of flaps. This helps the aircraft gain more lift for the same airflow. An aircraft only needs enough lift to counteract its own weight in normal operations (and a little more in turns), so there is no need for more lift, only to fly slower, with the same amount of lift. The increased drag also comes from the increased camber and wing area, as this makes the wing less efficient, with a lower lift-to-drag ratio. The steeper the flap angle, the higher the drag they will produce, and this is parasite drag, which increases with the square of the speed. content.question: Consider an aircraft flying in unaccelerated level flight in the speed stable region. How does the drag change following a sudden increase in CAS with no change in thrust available, and what will happen to the airspeed after this?

options.A: The total drag increases and the airspeed will decrease.
options.B: The total drag increases and the airspeed will further increase.
options.C: The induced drag increases and the airspeed will remain the same.
options.D: The parasite drag decreases and the airspeed will further increase.

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speedbrakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speedbrakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any gain of speed will result in an decrease in drag and further speed increase. The sudden change to a headwind (or a decrease in tailwind) can cause a gain of airspeed. Flying at a faster speed than VMD (front side), the aircraft will be in the stable speed region. Any increase of speed will result in an increase in drag. This increase in drag will cause the speed to decrease again (unless the thrust has changed). Therefore, a sudden increase in CAS, due to something like an increase in headwind (or a decrease in tailwind) can cause a momentary increase of airspeed, which eventually recues back to the original airspeed.

key_points: The coefficient of drag is a generic measure of the amount of drag exerted on an object in a particular fluid flow
It is not a force, it simply dictates "how draggy" an object (a wing or aircraft in our case) is
There are a few technical definitions for it, each one is correct, and explains it in a different way
learning.explanation: The coefficient of drag is a generic measure of the amount of drag exerted on an object in a particular fluid flow. It is not a force, it simply dictates "how draggy" an object (a wing or aircraft in our case) is. There are a few technical definitions for it, each one is correct, and explains it in a different way. To understand it, you must know that it is a way of comparing two objects, and how much drag force acts on them, for a specific size and dynamic pressure. The actual drag force is calculated by the formula D = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x CD x S where D = Drag (N) V = True Airspeed (m/s) CD = Coefficient of Drag S = Wing Area (surface area) (m2) The coefficient of drag is dimensionless, it has no units. One of its definitions is as follows, "The Drag Coefficient (CD) is a dimensionless number that is used to quantify the resistance of an object as it moves through a fluid.", as eluded to by this question.
